{{BLP sources|date=August 2016}} {{Orphan|date=August 2016}} {{ Infobox scientist | name = Elizabeth Gerber | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | fields = | workplaces = [[Northwestern University]] | alma_mater = [[Stanford University]]
[[Dartmouth College]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Robert I. Sutton|Robert Sutton]], [[Chip Heath]], [[Pamela Hinds]] | doctoral_students = | known_for = | awards = }} '''Elizabeth Gerber''' is an Associate Professor in the [[Segal Design Institute]], [[Mechanical Engineering]], and [[Technology and Social Behavior]] departments at [[Northwestern University]].{{cite web|url=https://www.mccormick.northwestern.edu/research-faculty/directory/|title=Faculty Directory: Northwestern's McCormick School of Engineering|publisher=[[Northwestern University]]}}{{cite web|url=http://tsb.northwestern.edu/people.php|title=People – Technology and Social Behavior|publisher=[[Northwestern University]]}} ==Early life and education== Gerber earned her B.A. at [[Dartmouth College]] in Studio Art and Engineering in 1998, and her M.S. at [[Stanford University]] in the Joint Program in Product Design in 2003. She earned her Ph.D. in Management Science & Engineering at Stanford University in 2007 working with [[Robert I. Sutton]], [[Chip Heath]], and [[Pamela Hinds]].[https://egerber.mech.northwestern.edu/?page_id=53 Elizabeth Gerber's Curriculum Vitae] ==Career== Gerber has been on the faculty at Northwestern University since 2008. Her primary appointments are in the Segal Design Institute (School of Engineering), Mechanical Engineering (School of Engineering), and Technology and Social Behavior Department (School of Communication). She holds additional appointments by courtesy in Industrial Engineering & Management Science (School of Engineering), Management & Organizations (School of Management), Learning Sciences (School of Education & Social Policy), and Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (School of Engineering). Gerber is the founder of Design for America, which is an organization of people dedicated to using design innovation for social good.[http://designforamerica.com Design for America] Her research in design focuses on collective innovation and design education. Collective innovation is the process and study (potentially) large groups of people who may not be familiar with design practice to work together to solve problems. Design education is thus related in that it considers how to teach students design. Gerber orients her research toward solving problems with positive social outcomes. ==Awards and honors== Gerber has received a number of awards and honors for her research, teaching, and outreach, such as the [[IEEE Computer Science and Engineering Undergraduate Teaching Award]].{{cite news|title=Northwestern Professor Liz Gerber Named 2014 Recipient of Computer Science and Engineering Undergraduate Teaching Award|url=https://www.computer.org/web/pressroom/northwestern-professor-liz-gerber-named-2014-recipient-of-undergraduate-teaching-award|accessdate=19 January 2017|agency=IEEE Computer Society|date=28 February 2014}} She was named among Crain's Chicago Business 40 under 40.[http://www.chicagobusiness.com/section/40under40-2013 Crain's Chicago Business 40 Under 40 2013] She has received multiple teaching awards at Northwestern University, including the University Teaching Award in 2016 [http://www.northwestern.edu/provost/faculty-honors/university-teaching-awards/award-recipients/index.html University Teaching Awards: Office of the Provost - Northwestern University] and the Elizabeth Hurlock Beckman Award in 2015.[https://www.wellsfargo.com/private-foundations/beckman-award-trust/ Elizabeth Hurlock Beckman Award Trust – Foundation Grants – Wells Fargo] == Selected publications == * E.M. Gerber, J.S. Hui, and P. Kuo. Crowdfunding: Why people are motivated to post and fund projects on crowdfunding platforms. International Workshop on Design, Influence, and Social Technologies: Techniques, Impacts and Ethics. 2012. * E.M. Gerber. Improvisation principles and techniques for design. SIGCHI conference on Human factors in computing systems. 2007. * M.D. Greenberg and E.M. Gerber. Learning to fail: experiencing public failure online through crowdfunding. Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems. 2014. * E.M. Gerber, J.M. Olson, and R.L. Komarek. Extracurricular design-based learning: Preparing students for careers in innovation. International Journal of Engineering Education. 2012. * M. Dontcheva, R.R. Morris, J.R. Brandt, and E.M. Gerber. Combining crowdsourcing and learning to improve engagement and performance. Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems. 2014. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gerber, Elizabeth}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Northwestern University faculty]] [[Category:Dartmouth College alumni]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:Computer science educators]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} '''Flying University''' ({{lang-pl|Uniwersytet Latający}}, less often translated as "Floating University") was an [[Counterculture|underground]] educational<ref name="LDJK">Betty Jean Lifton, ''The King of Children: The Life and Death of Janusz Korczak'', [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0312155603&id=cuK1wyWayOoC&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=%22Flying+University%22+underground&sig=2g91WxdFeB6AxkWU-cBBOG7ZeS8 p. 35], St. Martin's Press, 1997, {{ISBN|0-312-15560-3}}</ref> enterprise<ref name = "NaH1"> [[Peter Brock (historian)|Peter Brock]], John Stanley, Piotr J. Wróbel, ''Nation And History'', [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0802090362&id=lzWHDEE6OqkC&pg=PA167&lpg=PA167&vq=conspiratorial+enterprise&dq=%22Flying+University%22+Russia&sig=o6b3exqkuWPWfH5KAAgW8R0g8dc p. 167], University of Toronto Press, 2006, {{ISBN|0-8020-9036-2}}</ref> that operated from 1885 to 1905 in [[Warsaw]], the historic Polish capital, then under the control of the [[Russian Empire]], and that was revived between 1977 and 1981 in the [[People's Republic of Poland]]. The purpose of this and similar institutions was to provide Polish youth with an opportunity for an education within the framework of traditional Polish scholarship, when that collided with the ideology of the governing authorities. In the 19th century, such underground institutions were important in the national effort to resist [[Germanization]] under Prussian and [[Russification]] under Russian [[partitions of Poland|occupation]].<ref name="UHE">[[David Palfreyman]] (ed.), [[Ted Tapperm]], ''Understanding Mass Higher Education'', Routledge (UK), 2004, {{ISBN|0-415-35491-9}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0415354919&id=riv0UCM90AMC&pg=PA142&lpg=PA142&dq=%22Flying+University%22+Russification&sig=MVJ6bK6melK1V8sj4ofeJTSULto Google Print, pp. 141–142].</ref> In the communist [[People's Republic of Poland]], the Flying University provided educational opportunities outside [[Censorship in the People's Republic of Poland|government censorship]] and control of education.<ref name="Dilemmas">[[Barbara J Falk]], ''The Dilemmas of Dissidence in East-Central Europe: Citizen Intellectuals and Philosopher Kings'', Central European University Press, 2003, {{ISBN|963-9241-39-3}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN9639241393&id=ZsR0CGdWCC0C&pg=PA42&lpg=PA42&dq=%22Flying+University%22&sig=zu4Z2HAP8GfIWsG2aRUz0tCuyPo Google Print, p. 42].</ref>
==History==
=== Partitions === After the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] was [[partitions of Poland|partitioned]] in the late-18th century, its lands were divided among its neighbors: [[Imperial Russia]], [[Prussia]] and [[Austro-Hungary]]. [[Warsaw]], the historic Polish capital, fell under Russian control. In the Russian and Prussian partitions the situation of Poles progressively worsened.<ref name="UHE"/> Particularly in the Russian sector, the initially moderate ethnic policies were revised in the aftermath of the Polish revolts aimed at overthrowing Russian control, the [[November Uprising]] (1830–1831) and the [[January Uprising]] (1863–1864). Following the defeats of the uprising the autonomy of the [[Congress Poland]] was initially limited (1831) and finally abolished (1865).
Among the increasing policies of [[Germanization]] and [[Russification]], it became increasingly difficult for Poles to obtain a Polish [[higher education]].<ref name="UHE"/> Also, like in most parts of Europe at the time, the higher education opportunities for women that existed in the Russian Empire were severely limited,<ref name="Women">[[Christine Johanson]], ''Women's Struggle for Higher Education in Russia, 1855–1900'', McGill-Queen's Press, 1987, {{ISBN|0-7735-0565-2}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0773505652&id=B_BfKgWKDy8C&pg=PA23&lpg=PA23&dq=Polish+women+education+Russian&sig=abGkPXvchVcMsiA3WI5s4nm15vY Google Print, p. 23]</ref> and teaching or research into some fields, like [[Polish language]], [[Catholicism]] or [[Polish history]], ranged from difficult to illegal.<ref name="UHE"/><ref name="RR1905">[[Abraham Ascher]], ''The Revolution of 1905: A Short History'', Stanford University Press, 2004, {{ISBN|0-8047-5028-9}} [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0804750289&id=rNRqfGWR4pIC&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=Russification+education+Poland&sig=2Ua-OiKEPlnUKEOlh-2wV-s4gqo Google Print, p. 47].</ref><ref name="NaH">[[Peter Brock (historian)|Peter Brock]], John Stanley, Piotr J. Wróbel, ''Nation And History'', University of Toronto Press, 2006, {{ISBN|0-8020-9036-2}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0802090362&id=lzWHDEE6OqkC&pg=PA7&lpg=PA167&vq=Flying+University&dq=%22Flying+University%22+Russia&sig=ohWu6FpIyJQ3a2H30v_qOmJ77XA Google Print, p. 7].</ref>
As a response to such policies,<ref name="UHE"/><ref name="TEOIR">[[Peter Waldron]], ''The End of Imperial Russia, 1855–1917'', Palgrave, 1997, {{ISBN|0-312-16537-4}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0312165374&id=gvLExy_Z3PsC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120&dq=%22Flying+University%22+Russia&sig=bsfJl76F6_L2kXVC9TQCQcAm43Q Google Print, p. 120].</ref> and inspired by the [[Polish positivism]] movement,<ref name="WNBTH">[[Brian Porter (historian)|Brian Porter]], ''When Nationalism Began to Hate: Imagining Modern Politics in Nineteenth-Century Poland'', Oxford University Press US, 2002, {{ISBN|0-19-515187-9}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0195151879&id=qSWJ5WGSmJgC&pg=PA85&lpg=PA85&dq=%22Flying+University%22+Russia&sig=b6iawQ_KLGuN0A8Evie2v7KOXbk Google Print, p. 85].</ref> secret courses began in 1882 in private houses in Warsaw. At first it was a series of conspiratorial education courses for women, and among the first teachers were [[Józef Siemaszko]], [[Stanisław Norblin]], [[Piotr Chmielowski]] and [[Władysław Smoleński]]. In 1885 transformed due to the efforts of one of the students, [[Jadwiga Szczawińska]]<ref name="Korczak">[[Betty Jean Lifton]], ''The King of Children: The Life and Death of Janusz Korczak'', St. Martin's Press, 1997, {{ISBN|0-312-15560-3}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0312155603&id=cuK1wyWayOoC&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=%22Flying+University%22&sig=2g91WxdFeB6AxkWU-cBBOG7ZeS8 Google Print, pp. 35–40].</ref> (also known as Zofia Szczawińska<ref name="EW">[[Margarita Diaz-Andreu]], ''Excavating Women: A History of Women in European Archaeology'', Routledge (UK), 1998, {{ISBN|0-415-15760-9}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0415157609&id=RcsI5IvpocMC&pg=PA88&lpg=PA88&dq=%22Flying+University%22&sig=ya4wbGwpLlcWNg3GloCLVxW1z2M Google Print, p. 88].</ref>), the various pro-education groups were united into a single, informal, and illegal, secret university open for both sexes<ref name="Korczak"/> known as the Flying University (the courses, spread throughout the city, often changed locations to prevent the Russian authorities from learning the location and arresting the teachers and students<ref name="Korczak"/><ref name="EW"/>). The fees (2–4 [[Russian ruble|rubles]] per month) were used as gratification for the teachers, and to create a secret library. The [[curriculum]] of the Flying University covered 5–6 years with 8–11 hours per week and was divided into four main subjects: [[social sciences]], [[pedagogy]], [[philology]] and [[history]], and [[natural sciences]].
Among the teachers of the university were the best contemporary Polish academics,<ref name="EW"/> such as Władysław Smoleński and [[Tadeusz Korzon]] (history), [[Bronisław Chlebowski]], [[Ignacy Chrzanowski]], [[Zofia Daszyńska-Golińska]]<ref name=haan>{{cite book|last=Haan|first=edited by Francisca de|title=Biographical dictionary of women's movements and feminisms in Central, Eastern, and South Eastern Europe : 19th and 20th centuries|date=2005|publisher=Central European University Press|location=New York|isbn=9637326391|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?isbn=9637326391|edition=1st|author2=Daskalova, Krassimira|author3=Loutfi, Anna}}</ref> and Piotr Chmielowski (literature), [[Jan Władysław David]] and [[Adam Mahrburg]] (philosophy), [[Ludwik Krzywicki]] (sociology), [[Józef Nussbaum-Hilarowicz]] (biology).<ref name="Davies">[[Norman Davies]], ''[[God's Playground]]: A History of Poland'', Columbia University Press, 1982, {{ISBN|0-231-05352-5}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0231053525&id=DMoPXktGwiUC&pg=PA235&lpg=PA235&dq=%22Flying+University%22&sig=mALqwAUSy_O2qqrHk66FWLkiYKM Google Print, p. 235].</ref>
During the twenty years of the existence of the university, its courses were attended by approximately 5,000 women and thousands of men. Among the most famous of its students was the future [[Nobel Prize]] winner, [[Maria Skłodowska-Curie]], more commonly known as Madame Curie.<ref name="UHE"/><ref name="Davies"/> Other well known students included [[Zofia Nałkowska]] and [[Janusz Korczak]].<ref name="Korczak"/>
===Legalization=== Around 1905–1906 the Flying University was able to start legal activities, and was transformed into the Society of Science Courses (''Towarzystwo Kursów Naukowych''),<ref name="Davies"/> as Poland's partitioners, anticipating the [[First World War|coming war]], sought to convert the Poles to their cause.<ref name="UHE"/> Around 1918–1919, after Poland regained independence (as the [[Second Polish Republic]]), the Association was transformed into the private [[university]], [[Free Polish University]] (Wolna Wszechnica Polska).<ref name="Davies"/> In 1927 it founded a branch in [[Łódź]].
===World War II=== {{Main|Education in Poland during World War II}} During the [[Second World War]], when Poland was occupied by [[Nazi Germany]] which forbade Poles to attend university-level courses, many teachers of the Flying University used their experience and took part in [[education in Poland during World War II|secret teaching during World War II]].
===People's Republic=== After the Second World War, the Wolna Wszechnica Polska was not immediately recreated in Warsaw, although its branch in Łódź served as the foundation for the [[University of Łódź]].
During the [[History of Poland (1945–1989)|time of communist domination]] in the [[People's Republic of Poland]], as [[Education in the People's Republic of Poland|the curriculum became a tool of politics]], and much of [[Polish history]] (like the [[Polish-Soviet War]], [[Katyn Massacre]] or [[Praga Massacre]]) was [[censored]] in an attempt to 'erase' the history of Polish-Russian conflicts,<ref name="Ferro">[[Marc Ferro]], ''The Use and Abuse of History: Or How the Past Is Taught to Children'', Routledge, 2003, {{ISBN|0-415-28592-5}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0415285925&id=hDkeOWop9TsC&pg=PA259&lpg=PA259&dq=Suvorov+ordered+Praga&sig=dhghhzzFYdX1oAGaMx8ZoTQDsMI Google Print, p. 259].</ref> the tradition of the Flying University was revived once again, first by the Society of Free Polish University (Towarzystwo Wolnej Wszechnicy Polskiej) active in Warsaw from 1957, later from 1977 by the new Flying University and Society of Science Courses, supported by Polish [[dissident]]s: [[Stefan Amsterdamski]], [[Andrzej Celiński]], [[Bohdan Cywiński]], [[Aldona Jawłowska]], [[Jan Kielanowski]], [[Andrzej Kijowski]], [[Tadeusz Mazowiecki]], [[Wojciech Ostrowski]].
Many participants of this second flying university were abused by [[Milicja Obywatelska|milicja]], with common incidents like a prominent dissident, [[Jacek Kuroń]], being thrown down the stairs or his apartment ransacked by milicja-supported thugs; despite such harassment the Flying University was active until the imposition of [[martial law in Poland]] in 1981, which, although designed to destroy the [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity]] movement, stifled the flying university's activities too. With Solidarity's peaceful victory in the [[Polish legislative elections, 1989]], the goals of the Flying University — the freeing of Polish education from party's control and censorship — have been achieved.

{{Infobox person | name = Hans de Wit | image = Hans de Wit.jpg | image_size = | caption = Hans de Wit | birth_date = 10 November 1950 <ref>[http://www.albumacademicum.uva.nl Album Academicum] at the University of Amsterdam website</ref> | birth_place = [[Nijmegen]] | death_date = | death_place = | education = | occupation = International higher education specialist, author, researcher, professor. | title = Director, [[Center for International Higher Education]], [[Boston College]] | spouse = | parents = | children = | nationality = Dutch | website = }} '''Johannes Wilhelmus Maria "Hans" de Wit''' (born 1950) is a Dutch international [[educator]] and [[higher education]] administrator, known for his leading scholarly work on the field of [[Internationalization of Higher Education]].
==Current activities== Hans de Wit is since 2015 Director of the [[Center for International Higher Education]] (CIHE), based at [[Boston College]], USA, where he also serves as Professor.<ref name="universityworldnews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20150401104019621 |title=De Wit replaces Altbach at Boston College centre |publisher=University World News |date=2015-04-03 |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref> Before, he was founding Director of the ‘Centre for Higher Education Internationalisation’ (CHEI)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://centridiricerca.unicatt.it/chei-the-centre-presentazione |title=Presentazione - Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore |website=Centridiricerca.unicatt.it |date= |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref> at the [[Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore]] in [[Milan]], [[Italy]], and Professor of Internationalization of Higher Education at the [[Amsterdam University of Applied Sciences]].
He has widely consulted with the [[European Commission]], the [[European Parliament]], the [[World Bank]], the [[International Association of Universities]] and a variety of universities around the world, on matters related to Internationalization of Higher Education.
In 2014, he was a special advisor to the Study commissioned by the European Commission ‘The ERASMUS Impact Study: Effects of Mobility on the skills and Employability of Students and the Internationalization of Higher Education Institutions’.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/education/library/study/2014/erasmus-impact_en.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Erasmus Impact study |website=Ec.europa.eu |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref> He was a member of the Scientific Committee and Editorial Board of the second edition of the Bologna Process Researchers' Conference in Bucharest, on 24–26 November 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fohe-bprc.forhe.ro/ |title=Bologna Process Researchers Conference | Future of Higher Education |website=Fohe-bprc.forhe.ro |date=2014-11-26 |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref> He also was an advisor of the European Commission in the preparation of its communication ‘European Higher Education in the World’ <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.em-a.eu/fileadmin/content/Promo/Erasmus__in_the_world_layouted.pdf |format=PDF |title=European higher education in the world |website=Em-a.eu |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref> in 2013.
==Editorial work== De Wit is the Founding Editor of the ‘Journal of Studies in International Education’,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jsi.sagepub.com/ |title=Journal of Studies in International Education |website=Jsi.sagepub.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref> author and editor of several books on Internationalization of Higher Education,<ref>de Wit, Hans (2011). Trends, issues and challenges in internationalization of higher education. Amsterdam, Centre for Applied Research on Economics and Management.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/EXTLACREGTOPEDUCATION/Resources/Higher_Ed_in_LAC_Intnal_Dimension.pdf |format=PDF |title=Higher Education in Latin America |website=Siteresources.worldbank.org |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://www.bookdepository.com/Sage-Handbook-International-Higher-Education/9781412999212 |title=The Sage Handbook of International Higher Education |author1=Hans De Wit |author2=Darla K. Deardorff |author3=John D. Heyl |author4=Tony Adams |isbn=9781412999212 |website=Bookdepository.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref> and member of specialized editorial boards.
A prolific writer and blogger,<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.insidehighered.com/blogs/hans-de-wit |title=Hans de Wit's blog |website=Insidehighered.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20150811193137804 |title=School internationalisation: Whose opportunity? |publisher=University World News |date=2015-08-14 |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref> Hans de Wit is widely recognized as an influential scholar in the field of Internationalization of Higher Education.<ref name="universityworldnews1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Karen MacGregor |url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20120907122804742 |title=Bring internationalisation back into academia – Hans De Wit |publisher=University World News |date=2012-09-09 |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref>
==Early career== At the [[University of Amsterdam]], he served as Vice-President for International Affairs in 1986-2005. Also, he worked as director of international relations at [[Tilburg University]] (1981-1985) and assistant professor in Latin American Studies at [[Utrecht University]] (1979-1981).
==Education== He has a bachelor, master and PhD from the [[University of Amsterdam]].
==Public service== Hans de Wit is founding member and past president of the [[European Association for International Education]] [[EAIE]].
He is a Member of the Board of Trustees of [[World Education Services]], and Member of the Internationalisation Advisory Boards in several universities ([[Stenden University of Applied Sciences]] in The Netherlands, the [[University of Gottingen]] in Germany and the [[Cooperative University of Colombia]] in Medellin).
==Recognition== He has received several awards for his contribution to the field of international education: [[EAIE]] (1999 and 2008), [[NAFSA]] (2002), CIEE (2004 and 2006), [[University of Amsterdam]] (2006), AIEA (2006 and 2013) and [[AMPEI]] (2014).
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Wit, Hans de}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Dutch academics]] [[Category:Educational theorists]] [[Category:Boston College faculty]] [[Category:University of Amsterdam alumni]] [[Category:University of Amsterdam faculty]] [[Category:People from Nijmegen]] [[Category:Dutch expatriates in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox university |name = Kabul University |native_name =([[Pashto language|Pashto]]) دکابل پوهنتون ''Da Kābul Pohantūn''
([[Persian language|Dari]]) پوهنتون کابل ''Pohantūn-e Kābul'' |latin_name = Universitas Cabulensis |image = University of Kabul Logo.png |image_size = 300px |motto = ''Excellence in Service to Afghanistan'' |established = {{Start date and age|1932|paren=yes}} |type = |endowment = |staff = |faculty = |president = |provost = |student_body_president= |student_body_vice_president= |principal = |rector = = |head_label = |head = |students = |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |profess = |city = District 3, [[Kabul]] |state = |country = [[Afghanistan]] |campus = |free_label = |free = |colors = Black, red, and green {{Color box|black|border=darkgray}}{{Color box|red|border=darkgray}}{{Color box|green|border=darkgray}} |mascot = |nickname = |affiliations = |footnotes = |website = [http://www.ku.edu.af/ www.ku.edu.af] |address = |telephone = |coor = |logo = }} '''Kabul University''' ('''KU''') ([[Pashto language|Pashto]] دکابل پوهنتون ''Da Kābul Pohantūn '' / [[Persian language|Dari]] پوهنتون کابل ''Pohantūn-e Kābul'') is located in [[Kabul]], the capital of [[Afghanistan]]. It was founded in 1931 during the government of [[Mohammed Nadir Shah]] and then [[Prime Minister]] [[Mohammad Hashim Khan]] Kabul University is attended by approximately 25,000 students, of which around 40% are women. The main building was renovated about 500 metres from the old one, which has almost the same design. The mission of Kabul University is to mature and prosper as an internationally recognised institution of learning and research, a community of stakeholders committed to shared governance, and a centre of innovative thought and practice. ==History== [[File:1950s Afghanistan - Biology class, Kabul University.jpg|thumb|Biology class during the late 1950s or early 1960s.]] Kabul University was established in 1931 during the reign of Mohammed Nadir Shah and then Prime Minister Mohammad Hashim Khan, opening its doors one year later to students from across the country. It benefitted from partnerships with the governments of [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Russia]], and the [[United States]].{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1694972.stm | work=BBC News | title=Tunes of hope at Kabul University | date=6 December 2001}} In the 1960s foreign-educated scholars populated the campus, exposing the new generation to new topics such as [[communism]], [[feminism]] and [[capitalism]]. Students influenced during this era included [[Ahmad Shah Massoud]], [[Gulbuddin Hekmatyar]], Dr. [[Faiz Ahmad]], and [[Saydal Sokhandan]]. Many different political groups were influenced in the university such as [[Khalq]]ists, [[Parcham]]ites, [[Shola-y-Jaweid|Sholayees]], and [[Ikhwan]]ists. In a clash between Ikhwanis and Sholayees, a poet named Saydal Sokhandan was killed by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar in the 1970s. Saydal was fired upon and shot by Gulbuddin during an argument.[http://www.maoism.ru/alo/glossary.htm www.maoism.ru - Glossary of Names and Terms mentioned in the Historical Overview] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716183357/http://www.maoism.ru/alo/glossary.htm |date=16 July 2011 }} During the governance of the [[People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan|People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan (PDPA)]], Kabul University lost several lecturers and staff.{{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} The majority of the university's faculty left during the ten-year period of unrest or civil war that followed after the fall of the PDPA government in 1992. The area around the university and [[Karte Char]] was a major battleground in the [[Afghan Civil War (1992-96)]]. ===Rebuilding=== [[File:Zalmay Khalilzad and Ashraf Ghani at Kabul University in 2005.jpg|thumb|right|[[Zalmay Khalilzad]] & [[Ashraf Ghani]] in University Library 2005]] After the removal of the [[Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan|Taliban government]] in late 2001, the international community focused on rebuilding the educational institutions in Afghanistan. By January 2004 the campus had only 24 computers. As part of its recovery program the university has established partnerships with four foreign universities, including [[Purdue University]] and the [[University of Arizona]]. Furthermore, the Information Technology Center was founded in 2002 with the cooperation of [[German Academic Exchange Service]] (DAAD) and [[Technical University of Berlin]]. The number of students in higher education had increased across the country from 22,717 in 2002 to 56,451 in 2008. By 2008, the university was attended by 9,660 students, 2,336 (24%) of them being women. It was reported in 2007 that Iran donated funds to the university's [[dentistry]] faculty and donated 25,000 books. The main library of Kabul University was built by the United States, which is the best-equipped library in Afghanistan. It is equipped with computers, books and magazines. [[Nancy Dupree]], wife of [[Louis Dupree (professor)|Louis Dupree]], was the Director of the Afghanistan Center at the university. In 2008, the campus of Kabul University was provided with local network facilities by the [[Information Technology]] center of Kabul University (ITCK).[http://www.itck.af] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817053542/http://itck.af/ |date=17 August 2011 }} Each building is connected to the campus network and is provided with the internet connection from a fiber optic backbone. The [[Voice over IP]] (VoIP) technology was also part of the networking project, which improved the quality telephone communication at the university level. ==Structure== *The Faculty of Environment Science have Three Departments: Department of Environmental Protection, Department of Natural Resources and Management and Department of Natural Disaster Management.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/753/environment/educational-program | title = Educational Program | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-10 | quote = Faculty of environment science is established with three main departments, such as Environmental Protection, Natural Resources and Management, and Natural Disaster Management. General Science }} *The Faculty of Law and Political Sciences has four departments: Department of public law, Department of criminal law, Department of private law and Department of International Relation.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/social-science/882 | title = Brief history of the law and political sciences faculty | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-10 | quote = }} *The Faculty of Computer Science has four departments: Software engineering department, Computer science department, Information technology department and Information system department.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/753/857 | title = Brief history of Computer Science | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-10 | quote = }} *The Faculty of Economic has two shifts students (day and night), five active departments, three future planned departments.The day shifts’ departments are: Finance Department, Enterprise Management Department, Econometric and Statistic Department, National Economies Department, Management Information Systems Department, Counting Department (Future Plan), Money and Banking Department (Future Plan) and Economic Development Department (Future Plan). The night shifts’ departments are: Finance Department, Enterprise Management Department and National Economics Department.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/social-science/858/history | title = A Brief Introductionto Economics Faculty | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-10 | quote = }} *The Faculty of Science has four departments: Department of biology, Department of mathematics, Department of Chemistry and Department of physics.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/753/885 | title = Science | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-10 | quote = }} *The Faculty of Engineering has five departments: Mechanical engineering department, Electrical & electronics engineering department, Architectural department, Energy engineering department and Civil engineering department.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/753/876 | title = Engineering | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-10 | quote = }} An estimated 600 students are taking classes there. [[File:Engineering-Faculty-Final-logo1-optimized.png|thumb|right|Kabul University Engineering Faculty]] *The Faculty of Pharmacy has five departments: Department of Pharmacology-Toxicology, Department of Pharmaceutics, Department of Pharmacognosy, Department of Microbiology and Department of Biochemistry-Nutrition. It has eight laboratories.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/753/883 |title = Pharmacy |author = |date = |website = Kabul University |publisher = |access-date = 2018-11-10 |quote = }} An estimated 400 students are taking classes there. *The Faculty of Agriculture has six departments: Agronomy Department, Economics and Agricultural Extension Department, Forestry & Natural Resources Department, Department of Soil Science and Irrigation, Horticulture Department, and Plant Protection Department.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/753/856 |title = Agriculture |author= |date= |website = Kabul University |publisher= |access-date = 2018-11-10 |quote=}} *The Faculty of Veterinary Medicine has five departments: Department of Animal Production, Department of Para clinic, Department of Clinic, Department of Preclinical, and Department of food Hygiene and Technology.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/753/887 | title = Veterinary Medicine | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-10 | quote = }} *The Faculty of Journalism has two departments: Radio &TV Department and Press Department.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/social-science/880 | title = Journalism | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-10 | quote = }} *The [[Muhammad Iqbal|Allama Iqbal]] Faculty of Arts built at a cost of around $10 million by neighboring country Pakistan, was established in 2010. The building contains 28 classrooms, two seminar-halls, a library, two computer labs, 20 faculty offices. It covers an area of {{convert|143379|sqft|m2}}. Afghan and Pakistani officials inaugurated the building in July 2010. *The Faculty of Language and Literature have ten Departments: Pashto Language and Literature Department, Dari Language and Literature Department, The English Department, Russian Language Department, German Language Department, Turkish Language Department, Department of French Language, Arabic Language Department, Spanish Language Department and Chinese Language Department.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/social-science/881 | title = Language and Literature | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-11 | quote = }} *The Faculty of Fine Arts have six Departments: Sculpture Department, Painting Department, Graphic Department, Theatre Department, Music Department, playwright and screenwriting Department.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/social-science/877 | title = Brief History of the Fine Arts Faculty of Kabul University | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-11 | quote = }} *The Faculty of Islamic Studies have eight Departments: Religious Jurisprudence, Principles of Islamic Jurisprudence, Belief and Philosophy, Narrations of Prophet (Pbuh), Interpretation of Quran, Manner and Eloquence, Preaching of Islam and Islamic Culture.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/social-science/879/future-plan | title = Future Plan | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-11 | quote = }} *The Faculty of Social Science have three Departments: Archaeology and Anthropology Department, Philosophy Department and History Department.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/social-science/886 | title = Social Science | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-11 | quote = }} *Psychology and Educational Science Faculty has six departments: Education, Psychology, Administration, Management, Advisor and Instruction.{{cite web |url = http://ku.edu.af/en/page/social-science/884/history | title = History of Faculty | author = | date = | website = Kabul University | publisher = | access-date = 2018-11-11 | quote = Psychology and Educational Science Faculty has four departments: Education, Psychology, Administration and Management and in 2013 department of Advisor and Instruction will also be added. }} ===Faculty of Computer Science=== The faculty of Computer Science was separated from faculty of Natural Sciences in 2008. At that time the faculty had 17 lecturers, 215 students, 3 modern and equipped laboratories, one library, examination centre for long-distance exams, and was part of the CISCO regional project. The faculty has started lectures with three departments namely software engineering, information system and technology and database in 2010. The computer sciences faculty has close contacts with the [[University of Maryland]], [[University of Washington]], [[University of Cape Town]], [[Technical University of Berlin]] and the computer sciences department of all domestic universities. The graduates of the faculty can work in information technology centers of all governmental and non-governmental organizations.{{cite web|author=|url=http://ku.edu.af/en/page/857|title=Brief history of Computer Science Faculty of Kabul University|publisher=Islamic Republic of Afghanistan Ministry of Higher Education Kabul University|date=|accessdate=17 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120619180104/http://ku.edu.af/en/page/857|archivedate=19 June 2012|df=dmy-all}} == National Centre for Policy Research == The National Centre for Policy Research was established at Kabul University by the [[Ministry of Higher Education (Afghanistan)|Ministry of Higher Education]] and [[Konrad Adenauer Foundation]] in 2003, and includes faculty in the departments of Law and Politics, Economics, and Social Science.[http://ku.edu.af/en/page/7769 "Activities of Policy Research National Center of Kabul University," Kabul University website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022212838/http://ku.edu.af/en/page/7769 |date=22 October 2012 }} ''(accessed 2 January 2013)''[http://www.ncpr.af/ National Centre for Policy Research website] ''(accessed 2 January 2013)'' == Library == In 1992, the library held 200,000 books, 5,000 manuscripts, 3,000 rare books, periodicals, photographs and calligraphic specimens. Following a civil war, most materials were sold in book markets, burnt, destroyed, or lost.[http://www.worlib.org/vol08no2/rahin_v8n2.shtml The Situation of Kabul University Library: Its Past and Present] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/62yfxZsS3?url=http://www.worlib.org/vol08no2/rahin_v8n2.shtml |date=5 November 2011 }} It served as the National Library of Afghanistan. ==Notable alumni== *[[Ahmad Shah Massoud]], political and military leader *[[Wasef Bakhtari]], professor and poet *[[Hamida Barmaki]], law professor and Child Rights Commissioner *[[Mawlana Faizani]], philosopher and reformer *[[Qadria Yazdanparast]], legal advisor, human rights activist, Afghan Member of Parliament, head of Afghan Women High Association *[[Mohammad Najibullah]], President of Afghanistan (1987-1992) == See also == *[[List of universities in Afghanistan]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Kabul University}} *[http://www.ku.edu.af/ Official website of Kabul University] *[http://www.mohe.gov.af/ Official website of Ministry of Higher Education] {{coord|34|31|4|N|69|7|41|E|display=title|type:edu}} {{Asia topic|prefix=National Library of | title=[[National library|National libraries]] of Asia}} {{Afghan universities}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} [[Category:Kabul University| ]] [[Category:Universities in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Education in Kabul]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1932]] [[Category:1932 establishments in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Libraries established in 1932]]
