revision.text:
A '''semester school''' is a [[school]] that complements a student's [[secondary education]] by providing them with the opportunity to step out of their regular school for half an academic year and step into a uniquely different educational setting while continuing their required academic studies.[http://www.semesterschools.net/ Semester Schools Network][http://www.hotchkiss.org/Academics/Yr-Sem_OCPrograms.asp The Hotchkiss School - Semester Off-Campus Opportunities] The academic curriculum at semester schools tends to be college preparatory, interdisciplinary, and experiential.[http://www.nais.org/publications/ismagazinearticle.cfm?itemNumber=150703 National Association of Independent Schools: Semester Schools] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611164221/http://www.nais.org/publications/ismagazinearticle.cfm?itemNumber=150703 |date=2011-06-11 }}[http://www.petersons.com/common/article.asp?id=1171&path=hs.fas.advice&sponsor=1 Peterson's Semester Schools: Great Opportunities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627023207/http://www.petersons.com/common/article.asp?id=1171&path=hs.fas.advice&sponsor=1 |date=2010-06-27 }}[http://www.privateschoolreview.com/articles/145 Private School Review: Semester Schools] ==Characteristics== *Semester school curricula are built around themesInformation from a review of semester school websites including [[environmental sustainability]], [[marine ecology]], [[organic farming]], ethics and leadership, [[visual arts]], and others. The curricula tend to be place-based drawing on the resources and opportunities of each school's unique location.[http://www.collegebound.net/content/living-learning-at-semester-schools/ College Bound Network: Living and Learning at Semester Schools] *Semester schools are [[boarding school]]s. Community living is a key element of the experience. Through living closely with peers and teachers and working together to benefit the school community students develop their communication, leadership, and cooperative skills. *Semester schools enroll college bound sophomores, juniors, and or seniors. Most semester schools focus primarily on students from just one grade level. *Semester school programs run from 14 to 18 weeks. *Semester schools tend to be small, enrolling from 15 to 60 students a semester with average class sizes ranging from 5 to 15 students. *Semester schools are [[private school]]s that charge [[tuition]] and offer financial aid. Depending on the school and a student’s family situation the cost can range from no cost to several thousands of dollars. *Most semester schools are located in the [[United States]]. *While most semester schools serve students in secondary school or high school, Steward Outdoor School in [[Ivoryton, Connecticut|Ivoryton]], CT serves [[middle school]] students. ==Benefits== Attending a semester school can: *Intensify a student’s interest in and motivation for learning. [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/05/education/edlife/farmm.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2 New York Times - Semester Away] *Allow a student to pursue a special area of interest in depth. [https://www.coastalstudiesforgirls.org/.../SEEN%20Magazine%20Semester%20Schools.pdf SEEN Magazine - Semester school programs]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *Complement a student's education with experiences that aren't available at their home school.[http://www.lovett.org/academics/travel-programs/semester-school-programs/index.aspx The Lovett School - Semester School Programs] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626205845/http://www.lovett.org/academics/travel-programs/semester-school-programs/index.aspx |date=2009-06-26 }} *Broaden a student’s range of skills and interests and increase their maturity level. *Give students a [[Head start (positioning)|head start]] on developing the independence, good judgment, and life skills necessary for living away from home before they leave for college. *Provide students with a unique, eye-catching experience that sets them apart from other applicants when applying to colleges.[http://www.collegebound.net/gapyear-programs/article/a-new-adventure-at-semester-schools/8842/ College Bound Network: A New Adventure at Semester Schools] *Provide students from public schools a boarding school experience without the cost or time commitment of a four-year school. ==Growth== The first semester school was Milton Academy's Mountain School which opened in 1984 in Vershire, Vermont. Since then more than a dozen additional semester schools have opened across the United States of America and in other countries. The list of opening dates below shows the growth in semester schools over time and their geographic diversity.
:1984 – [http://www.mountainschool.org Mountain School], Vershire, Vermont :1986 – [http://www.swisssemester.org/ Swiss Semester], Zermatt, Switzerland :1988 – [http://www.mainecoastsemester.org Maine Coast Semester], Maine Coast Semester at Chewonki, Wiscasset, Maine :1995 – [https://web.archive.org/web/20110903032914/http://www.enf.org/outdoor_academy The Outdoor Academy], Pisgah Forest, North Carolina :1996 – [http://www.cityterm.org/ CITYterm], Dobbs Ferry, New York :1997 – High School Semester at Sea (Ocean Classroom), Western North Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea (closed July 2014) :1998 – [http://www.hminet.org/HMIsemester HMI Semester], Leadville, Colorado (originally named Rocky Mountain Semester) :1999 – [http://www.islandschool.org/ The Island School], Cape Eleuthera, Bahamas :1999 – [http://www.oxbowschool.org/ Oxbow School], Napa, California :2000 – [http://www.travelingschool.com/ The Traveling School], Bozeman, Montana :2004 – [http://semester.woolman.org/ Woolman Semester], Nevada City, California :2004 – [https://web.archive.org/web/20111211162437/http://www.kroka.org/semester/semester.shtml Kroka Semester School], Marlow, New Hampshire :2009 – [http://schoolforethics.org/ School for Ethics and Global Leadership], Washington, D.C. :2009 – [http://www.findingthegood.org Finding the Good], Nevada City, California :2010 – [http://www.coastalstudiesforgirls.org/ Coastal Studies for Girls], Freeport, Maine :2010 – [[Conserve School]], Land O’ Lakes, Wisconsin :2012 – [[Alzar School]], Valley County, Idaho :2012 – [https://web.archive.org/web/20120831114922/http://www.burrburton.org/page.cfm?p=661 Burr and Burton Academy Mountain Campus], Manchester, Vermont :2016 – [http://www.stewardoutdoorschool.org/ Steward Outdoor School] Ivoryton, Connecticut ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Semester schools| ]] [[Category:School types]] [[Category:Boarding schools]] [[Category:Experiential learning]]

page.title: Society of Pakistan English Language Teachers

revision.text:
'''Society of Pakistan English Language Teachers''' ('''SPELT''') is a professional forum for practitioners teaching English as a foreign/second language to facilitate effective communication and improve the teaching/learning standards of English in [[Pakistan]].
==Introduction== The Society of Pakistan English Language Teachers SPELT was formed in 1984 in [[Karachi]], Pakistan.<ref>{{cite book |title=Language, ideology and power: language learning among the Muslims of Pakistan and North India |last=Rahman |first=Tariq |year=2002 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=978-0-19-579644-5 |page=316 }}</ref> It is dedicated to improving the standard of [[English language learning and teaching]] in Pakistan.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Shamim |first=Fauzia |date=September 2008 |title=Trends, issues and challenges in English language education in Pakistan |journal=Asia Pacific Journal of Education |publisher=[[Routledge]] |volume=28 |issue=3 |pages=235–249 |issn=0218-8791 |doi=10.1080/02188790802267324 }}</ref> SPELT enables maximum exploitation of the limited resources available in the country. It attempts to be well-informed about recent developments in teaching techniques,<ref>{{cite news |title=23rd international SPELT conference opens: We don’t just need goras to teach us English: experts |url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2007\11\03\story_3-11-2007_pg12_7 |work=[[Daily Times (Pakistan)|Daily Times]] |date=3 November 2007 |accessdate=26 May 2009 }}</ref> which invariably need to be modified in order to suit the needs and limitations of the Pakistan situation. It is affiliated with a number of international [[professional association]]s like [[TESOL Inc.|Teachers of English to Speakers of Other Languages]] (TESOL) and [[International Association of Teachers of English as a Foreign Language]] (IATEFL), and is supported by the [[British Council]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Three-day SPELT conference opens: Discussing vanishing borders; global English |url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2006\09\16\story_16-9-2006_pg11_3 |work=[[Daily Times (Pakistan)|Daily Times]] |date=16 September 2006 |accessdate=26 May 2009 }}</ref>
==Mission== SPELT's mission is to provide a professional forum for practitioners teaching English as a foreign/second language to facilitate effective communication and improve the teaching/learning standards of English in Pakistan.
==Activities== *Teacher development courses.<ref>{{cite book |title=Transforming schools in Pakistan: towards the learning community |last=Retallick |first=John |author2=Iffat Farah |year=2005 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=978-0-19-597900-8 |page=xii }}</ref> *Two hour academic session every month. *International conference every year.<ref>{{cite book |title=Portraits of literacy across families, communities, and schools: intersections and tensions |last=Anderson |first=Jim |author2=Maureen Kendrick |author3=Theresa Rogers |author4=Suzanne Smythe |year=2005 |publisher=[[Routledge]] |isbn=978-0-8058-4859-5 |page=227 }}</ref> *Networking of teachers worldwide through courses and conferences.<ref>{{cite news |title=24th Spelt moot begins at FJWU |url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/daily_detail.asp?id=143070 |work=[[The News International]] |date=25 October 2008 |accessdate=26 May 2009 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> *Publication of the journal ''SPELT Quarterly''.<ref>{{cite book |title=Language planning in higher education: a case study of Pakistan |last=Mansoor |first=Sabiha |year=2005 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=978-0-19-597860-5 |page=44 }}</ref>
==International conference== This conference will provide a forum for teachers to understand and link teaching theories and practices in the classroom. It will is an excellent opportunity to see theory and practice as two sides of the same coin and to network. Papers, presentations and workshops will cover themes of classroom practices, learner-centered approach, research in language teaching/learning and the relationship between language teaching and language learning.
==See also== *[[English language learning and teaching]] *[[Teaching English as a foreign language]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.spelt.org.pk Society of Pakistan English Language Teachers website] *[http://www.tutorfinder.com.pk Tutor Finder]
[[Category:English-language education]] [[Category:Language education in Pakistan]] [[Category:Pakistani English]] [[Category:1984 establishments in Pakistan]]

{{Infobox website | name = TES Australia | logo = | logocaption = | url = {{URL|http://www.tesaustralia.com/}} | location = [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]] | type = [[Education]] | registration = Optional (required only for the upload/download of resources) | owner = [[TES Connect]] | launch date = {{Start date and age|p=y|mf=yes|2013|7|11}} | commercial = Yes | current status = Active }}
'''TES Australia''' is a free teaching resources website with over 565,000 resources.<ref>http://www.tesaustralia.com/</ref> It launched in July 2013.
== History ==
TES Australia is owned and operated by [[TES Connect]], it is the world's largest supplier of educational teacher exchange resources.<ref>http://www.aeufederal.org.au/Publications/AE/Win13pp22-23.pdf</ref> TES Connect was launched in April 2006 to provide teachers with a way to share and find resources.
TES Australia was developed and launched in partnership with the [[Board of Studies]],<ref>http://www.boardofstudies.nsw.edu.au/</ref> the [[Australian Education Union]] <ref>http://www.aeufederal.org.au</ref> and the Centre for Professional Learning New South Wales<ref>http://www.cpl.asn.au/</ref> to offer a free online platform for high-quality teaching resources mapped to the Australian curriculum.<ref>http://www.aeufederal.org.au/Publications/AE/Win13pp22-23.pdf</ref>
== Resources and Community ==
TES Australia launched with over 565,000 resources arranged by stage, subject and topic. As well as pre-school/early childhood, primary and secondary-level resources, the site also has resources suitable for whole school topics and for children with special educational needs.<ref>http://www.tesaustralia.com/teaching-resources/</ref>
Teachers can also get news and information about the [[Australian Curriculum]] in a dedicated information centre.<ref>http://www.tesaustralia.com/article.aspx?storyCode=7000280</ref>
In addition, TES Australia has a community section, where teachers can join groups, discuss topics in forums or write their own blogs <ref>http://community.tesaustralia.com/</ref>
== Ownership ==
[[TES Connect]] is run by TES Global, which has been owned by TPG Capital LLP since 2013<ref>http://www.tsleducation.com/news-and-press/080713.html</ref>
== See also == [[Times Educational Supplement]]
[[Share My Lesson]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|www.tesaustralia.com/}} * [http://www.tesconnect.com/ TES Connect] * [https://tpg.com/ TPG Capital LLP]
[[Category:Education in Australia]]

{{primary sources|date=May 2010}} {{Infobox organization | name = The Association for Science Education | image = Association for Science Education (UK).gif | image_border = | size = 240 | alt = | caption = | map = | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = ASE | motto = | predecessor = *Association of Public School Science Masters
*Science Masters Association
*Association of Women Science Teachers | successor = | formation = 1900's | extinction = | type = [[Learned society]] and [[Professional association]] | status = | purpose = | headquarters = [[University of Hertfordshire]] | location = [[College Lane]]
[[Hatfield, Hertfordshire|Hatfield]]
[[Hertfordshire]]
AL10 9AA
[[United Kingdom]] | coords = | region_served = | membership = | language = English | general = | leader_title = Patron | leader_name = Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh | leader_title2 = President | leader_name2 = Prof. Danielle George | leader_title3 = Chair of the Association | leader_name3 = Linda Needham | leader_title4 = Chief Executive | leader_name4 = Shaun Reason | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{URL|https://www.ase.org.uk/home/}} | remarks = '''Motto''':
''Promoting Excellence in Science Teaching and Learning'' | former name = }} '''The Association for Science Education''' ('''ASE''') is a professional [[Professional association|association]] in the [[United Kingdom]] for teachers of science and science technicians.{{cite journal|last=|first=|year=1998|title=The Nature of Science in Science Education: An Introduction|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1008642510402#page-1|journal=Science & Education|volume=7|pages=511–532|doi=10.1023/A:1008642510402|via=}} The association was formed in 1963 and is a member of the UK [[Science Council]]. == Aims == The Royal Charter of the Association for Science Education{{Cite web|url=http://www.ase.org.uk/about-ase/royal-charter/|title=Royal Charter - The Association for Science Education|website=www.ase.org.uk|access-date=2016-12-13}} States, "The objects and purposes for which The Association is hereby constituted are the promotion of education by the following means: (a) by improving the teaching of science and (b) by providing an authoritative medium through which opinions of teachers of science may be expressed on educational matters and (c) by affording means of communication among all persons and bodies of persons concerned with the teaching of science in particular and with education in general." ==History== The ASE formed in 1963 by the merger of the [[Science Masters Association]] and the [[Association of Women Science Teachers]]. The Association for Science Education can trace its origins back to 1900. The first Annual Meeting was held in January 1901 which then led to the formation of the Association of Public School Science Masters. Incorporated by Royal Charter in October 2004, the ASE operates as a Registered Charity.{{Cite web|url=http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=313123&SubsidiaryNumber=0|title=Charity Commission|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} The history of the ASE can be found in two publications: ''Interpreters of Science''{{Cite book|title=Interpreters of Science: History of the Association for Science Education|last=David|first=Layton|publisher=John Murray Publishers Ltd|year=1984|isbn=978-0719541858|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}} by David Layton and, published to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the association, ''Advancing Science Education: the first fifty years of the Association for Science Education'',{{Cite book|title=Advancing Science Education: the first fifty years of the Association for Science Education|last=Edgar|first=Jenkins|publisher=Association for Science Education|year=2013|isbn=9780863574351|location=United Kingdom|pages=|quote=|via=}} Edited by Edgar Jenkins and Valerie Wood-Robinson. The Patron of the Association is [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|HRH Prince Philip]], Duke of Edinburgh, KG,PC,KT, GMBE, FRS. ==Activities== The Association promotes improvements in science education and education in general, specifically through advice and support for teachers, technicians and others with meetings and conferences, journals and resources, curriculum and professional development programmes and contributions to research and policy debates. ===[https://web.archive.org/web/20100514161940/http://www.ase.org.uk/htm/book_store/index.php Bookshop]=== The ASE is a specialist publisher for the science education market. This includes approximately 200 titles ranging from Primary to Secondary and Post 16 science education. ===Journals=== The ASE produces four journals which not only keep members up to date with developments in science education but also provide ideas and tips for the delivery of science education. Their journals include: *Education in Science - the in house journal keeping members up to date with ASE developments.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ase.org.uk/journals/education-in-science/|title=Education in Science - The Association for Science Education|website=www.ase.org.uk|access-date=2016-12-13}} *Primary Science ''(previously: Primary Science Review)'' - aimed at the primary sector, giving ideas for lessons and developments in primary science education.http://www.ase.org.uk/journals/primary-science/ *School Science Review - aimed at the secondary sector, giving ideas for lessons and developments in primary science education.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ase.org.uk/journals/school-science-review/|title=School Science Review - The Association for Science Education|website=www.ase.org.uk|access-date=2016-12-13}} *Science Teacher Education - aimed at providers of initial teacher training and aims to inform and contribute to the development of science teacher education in all phases of education.http://www.ase.org.uk/journals/science-teacher-education/ === Annual Conference === The annual conference attracts over 3000 delegates and include 350+ talks and workshops ranging from academic lectures and exhibitions, to a social programme and themed days. == Governance == An elected '''Education Group''' governs and controls the affairs of the Association. The Education Group advises the Trustees on all aspects of science education. Its 30 members represent all sectors of the science education community and speaks authoritatively on behalf of the Association. The group is led by the Chair of the Association and meets 3 times a year. The Chair of the Association is elected by the membership and serves a term of one year. '''The Trustee Body''' has responsibility for ensuring that ASE works properly as a charity, that the finances are properly regulated and monitored and the appropriate policies are in place. The trustees meets 3 times a year and consists of 11 member trustees. === List of Presidents and Association Chairs from 1963-2016 === {| class="wikitable" !Year !Presidents !Association Chair |- |2016 |[[Danielle George|Professor Danielle George]] |Ms Corinne Stevenson |- |2015 |[[David Bell (university administrator)|Sir David Bell]] |Ms Christine Harrison |- |2014 |[[Alice Roberts|Professor Alice Roberts]] |Mr Pete Robinson |- |2013 |[[Martin Rees|Professor Martin Rees, Lord Rees of Ludlow]] |Mrs Liz Lawrence |- |2012 |Professor Robin Millar |Mrs Lynne Horton |- |2011 |[[Steve Jones (biologist)|Professor Steve Jones]] |Mr Richard Needham |- |2010 |Sir Alan Jones |Mr [[Manoj Chitnavis]] |- |2009 |Professor Wynne Harlen |Ms Carolyn Yates |- |2008 |Professor Micheal Earwicker |Mr Graham Kingsley |- |2007 |[[Julia Higgins|Professor Dame Julia Higgins]] |Ms Charlotte Clarke |- |2006 |[[Gareth Roberts (physicist)|Sir Gareth Roberts]] |Mr Bob Kibble |- |2005 |[[Mike Tomlinson|Sir Mike Tomlinson]] |Mr David Bevan |- |2004 |Sir [[Peter Williams (physicist)|Peter Williams]] |Dr Susan Burr |- |2003 |Dr Gill Samuels |Ms Sue Flanagan |- |2002 |[[Patrick Jenkin, Baron Jenkin of Roding|Lord Jenkin of Roding]] |Mr Ian Galloway |- |2001 |Professor [[Patrick J. Dowling|Patrick Dowling]] |Dr Derek Bell |- |2000 |[[Susan Greenfield, Baroness Greenfield|Professor Susan Greenfield]] |Mrs Rebecca Edwards |- |1999 |[[John Horlock|Sir John Horlock]] |Miss Rosemary Feasey |- |1998 |Mr David Brown |Mr Roger McCune |- |1997 |Sir [[Brian Follett]] |Mrs Mary Ratcliffe |- |1996 |Sir [[Neil Cossons]] |Mrs Jane Wheatley |- |1995 |[[Bridget Ogilvie|Dr Bridget Ogilvie]] |Mr David Standley |- |1994 |Dr David Giachardi |Mr Philip Ramsden |- |1993 |Professor {{ill|Roger Blin-Stoyle|de}} |Miss Maggie Hannon |- |1992 |Sir [[Basil John Mason|John Mason]] |Dr Boyd Gunnell |- |1991 |Professor [[Hans Kornberg]] |Mrs Elizabeth Preston |- |1990 |Sir Dick Morris CBE |Mr E.O. Scott |- |1983 |Sir [[Robert James Clayton|Robert Clayton]] CBE FEng |Miss Ruth Schofield |- |1982 |Sir [[Hermann Bondi]] KCB FRS |Mr Maurice Savory |- |1981 |Sir [[Denis Rooke]] CBE FRS FEng |Mr Jeff Thompson |- |1980 |Sir Norman Lindop |Mr John Healey |- |1979 |Mr Norman Booth |Mr A.R. The '''British School''' is a private international school in Nepal delivering the English [[National Curriculum (England, Wales and Northern Ireland)|National Curriculum]] with full-time UK recruited staff. The school was founded in 1966 to serve the British community but it is an inclusive school which has over 35 different nationalities as of 2015.
The school plans to move to a purpose-built new school with capacity large enough for around 650 students.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2016-12-11/intl-accolade-to-british-school-kathmandu.html|title=Int’l accolade to British School Kathmandu|access-date=2018-09-11|language=en}}</ref> The school is based in [[Sanepa]] and has its own astroturf pitches, two multi-purpose sports areas, science laboratories, a Sixth Form Centre, and a duck pond. It also has many small gardens around the area and a parking lot for the staff and students.It has two libraries, one for primary and one for secondary. The school also has bike stands for cyclists.

'''Thomas Hodson''' was a Wesleyan Missionary, who served in [[India]], in the Wesleyan Canarese Mission, at the [[Bengaluru Pete|Bangalore Petah]] and [[Gubbi]]. Thomas helped in running the first Wesleyan Mission Canarese school in the erstwhile Mysore State. Thomas was a linguist and a [[Kannada]] scholar, and was also fluent in [[Tamil Language|Tamil]] and [[Bengali language|Bengali]]. Hodson helped in establishing the Wesleyan Canarese Chapel (now the [[Hudson Memorial Church, Bangalore|Hudson Memorial Church]]) at Nagarthpete in the Bangalore Petah. In 1864, Hodson wrote ''An Elementary Grammar of the Kannada, or Canarese Language'', a treatise on the grammar of the Kannada language.<ref name=Offering1857 /><ref name=Moister>{{cite book|last1=Moister|first1=William|title=Missionary worthies, being brief memorial sketches of ministers sent forth by the Wesleyan missionary society who have died in the work from the beginning|date=1885|publisher=T Woolmer|location=London|accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=HHT>{{cite web|last1=Hodson|first1=Thomas|title=School and schoolhouse, Bangalore - Hodson's letter Dec 24 1836|url=http://collection.hht.net.au/firsthhtpictures/fullRecordPicture.jsp?recnoListAttr=recnoList&recno=42467|website=Historic Houses Trust|accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref>
==History== Thomas Hodson was born in 1804, at [[North Scarle]], [[Lincolnshire]], [[England]]. In 1829, we came to India as a missionary of the Wesleyan Mission. Initially he was stationed in [[Calcutta]] between 1829-1833, where he learned [[Bengali Language|Bengali]] for nearly 3 years. Between 1833-1836, he was transferred to [[Bangalore]], where he learnt [[Canarese]] and [[Tamil language|Tamil]]. In 1836, he was appointed to [[Mysore]], and then to [[Gubbi]] in 1837. Appointed back to Mysore, he served between 1838-1843. In 1843, he returned to England due to bad health. However, in 1853, he returned to India, and was appointed the Chairman and Superintendent of the Wesleyan Canarese Mission in the Mysore District. Leaving India in March 1878, for England where he died on 9 September 1882.<ref name=HHT /><ref name=Minutes>{{cite journal|title=Continental India: The Madras District|journal=Minutes of Several Conversations at the ... Yearly Conference of the People Called Methodists|volume=7|page=376|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=DCIRAAAAIAAJ&dq=thomas+g+hodson+missionary+bangalore&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=20 November 2015|publisher=Wesleyan Methodist Church|location=London}}</ref><ref name=Mason>{{cite journal|last1=Mason|first1=John|title=Madras District|journal=The Wesleyan-Methodist Magazine|date=1833|volume=56|page=652|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=fnFJAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA652&lpg=PA652&dq=thomas+g+hodson+missionary+bangalore&source=bl&ots=GmiyUhhbMh&sig=sl98Fzo_IgNm0uKMfJU7gqZ5OXQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwie0rTNop7JAhXC5KYKHQ6XA_0Q6AEIJDAC#v=onepage&q=thomas%20g%20hodson%20missionary%20bangalore&f=false|accessdate=20 November 2015|publisher=Methodist Church|location=London}}</ref>
Mary Ann Hodson, the wife of Thomas died on 10 August 1866, aged 68 years, and is buried at the Agram Protestant Cemetery in Bangalore. The Agram cemetery also has the graves of Jane Peach Rice wife of Benjamin Rice of the [[London Missionary Society]] who died on 11 March 1864 aged 57, Catherine wife of Matthew Trevan Male of the Wesleyan Missionary Society who died on 29 August 1865 aged 49, Fanny Lees child of Catherine and Matthew Male born 29 January 1861 and died 24 April 1861, and Rev. Alexander Maceallum, Missionary of the Free Church of Scotland died 10 June 1862.<ref name="Agram">{{cite web|last1=Johnson|first1=Ronnie|title=The Old Protestant Cemetery or Agram Cemetery|url=http://geocitiessites.com/Athens/2960/grave1.htm|website=Bangalore Walla|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref>
After the death of his first wife Mary Ann, Thomas married Sophia Simpson (born 1836) and had another child Margaret Hodson born in 1871. Thomas also had a son from his first marriage, Richard George Hodson (born 1830),<ref name="Ancestry1">{{cite web|title=Thomas Hodson|url=http://www.ancestry.com.au/genealogy/records/thomas-hodson_84757649|website=Ancestry|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref><ref name="Ancestry2">{{cite web|title=Sophia Simpson|url=http://www.ancestry.com.au/genealogy/records/sophia-simpson_63297626|website=Ancestry|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> who has contributed articles on Bangalore in the Wesleyan Magazine.
==In Bangalore== Arriving in Bangalore from Calcutta, Thomas Hodson and his wife, temporarily lived at the Wesleyan Mission House at the [[Bangalore Cantonment]], along with Rev. Hardy. His initial days was spent learning Kannada and Tamil. In particular, Hodson intended to follow the example of the American missionaries in [[Ceylon]] and establish an extensive educational system in Bangalore.
According to Captain Woodward of the 32 NI, reporting on 4 November 1832, the Wesleyan Mission was established in the [[Bangalore Cantonment]] in 1819. The contact till then was restricted to the Tamil population of the Cantonment and the English soldiers. A Wesleyan Chapel had been established in the Bangalore Cantonment (the present Wesley Tamil Church, Haines Road), and services were conducted regularly in Tamil and 1 service every Sunday for the English soldiers. Contact with the Canarese population of the [[Bengaluru Pete|Bangalore Pettah]] was restricted. For reaching out to the Canarese, Thomas Hodson was learning the language, so he would be able to interact with them.<ref name="CalcuttaObserver1834">{{cite journal|last1=Hodson|first1=Thomas|title=Methodist Mission, Madras|journal=The Calcutta Christian Observer|date=January 1834|volume=3|issue=1|pages=50–51|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=3LYOAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA50&lpg=PA50&dq=mrs+little+wesleyan+school+bangalore&source=bl&ots=fuKAPwtzUZ&sig=U-NjAf9B4GdZplWNFyTK0jgwkEk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiQ2ZuDn43MAhWF2KYKHQh5Av4Q6AEIODAH#v=onepage&q=mrs%20little%20wesleyan%20school%20bangalore&f=false|accessdate=14 April 2016}}</ref>
In 1832, Hodson was appointed to Bangalore, along with Peter Percival. Wesleyan missionaries were supposed to take up the dual task of educating and preaching to the locals. Around this time, Hodson decided to start a Mission at [[Gubbi]], which a native town in the [[Kingdom of Mysore|Mysore Kingdom]]. The reason for Hodson choosing Gubbi to set up the mission was that, in Bangalore he found that his time and efforts were taken away in preaching to the British and European officers, and he could not concentrate on the local population. However, the Gubbi mission was temporarily abandoned and Hodson returned to Bangalore. In 1834, Hodson purchased about 20 acres of land, just outside the [[Bengaluru Pete|Bangalore Petah]] (the current [[United Mission School]] and College, Unity Buildings, etc.). In the same year, Hodson had to take up the role of Supervisor of the Wesleyan Tamil Mission. During his tenure, he started an Anglo-Tamil school in the [[Bangalore Cantonment|Bangalore Civil and Military Station]]. The reputation of the school spread, and several respected Hindu gentlemen of the Petah, requested Hodson to open a Canarese School in the Petah. Hence, a room was rented within the Fort walls and Canarese (Kannada) school was started. In this room, Hodson preached his first sermon in Canarese in 1835.
For some time, Hodson was involved in managing the [[Tamil language|Tamil]] works at Bangalore. After some time he moved back to [[Gubbi|Goobie]], living out in a tent. Rev. Thomas Cryer took over from Hodson as the Supervisor of the Wesleyan Tamil Mission. At this time [[William Arthur (minister)|William Arthur]] (an Irishman, after whom the [[William Arthur Memorial Church, Gubbi|William Arthur Memorial]] [http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-xIn7fk6E6RE/UI5BUmvFQoI/AAAAAAAADLs/It8pDKDZmw4/s1600/church+gub.JPG Church] at [[Gubbi|Goobie]] is named after) and Peter Batchelor, laymen who came to Madras to run the Church Ministry Service (CMS) Press joined the Wesleyan Mission, and were transferred to the Weslyan Tamil Mission at [[Bangalore Cantonment]]. Arthur them moved to Gubbi as the Wesleyan missionary.<ref name=Pritchard>{{cite book|last1=Pritchard|first1=John|title=Methodists and their Missionary Societies 1760-1900|date=28 Sep 2013|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=OgaiAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT114&lpg=PT114&dq=thomas+hodson+missionary+bangalore&source=bl&ots=bv9OMK26us&sig=NJ_kl5ZZ_QT1e5mH1SFocv_ekr8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiw9NqOpp7JAhUBeaYKHRTmB4sQ6AEIMDAF#v=onepage&q=thomas%20hodson%20missionary%20bangalore&f=false|accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> Thomas Hodson recorded the experiences of the Gubbi Mission in his book ''Old Daniel, or, Memoir of a converted Hindoo: with observations on mission work in the Goobbe circuit and description of village life in India'', which provides an excellent account of village life in the 19th century Mysore State.<ref name=OldDaniel /><ref name=Findlay>{{cite book|last1=Findlay|first1=George Gillanders|last2=Holdsworth|first2=William West|title=The history of the Wesleyan Methodist Missionary Society: Volume 5|date=1921|publisher=The Epworth Press|location=London|pages=206-107|url=https://archive.org/details/historyofwesleya05find|accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref>
==Wesleyan Canarese Mission== According to [[William Arthur (minister)|William Arthur]], the Wesleyan Canarese Mission was located in the [[Bengaluru Pete|Bangalore Petah]], at about 3 miles from the Wesleyan Tamil Mission house. The land for the Wesleyan Canarese Mission was obtained by Thomas Hodson, and was located just outside one of the town gates. Initially, it was a school with a school room which served as the residence of the school master. The school provided English education and considerable number of students were enrolled. Thereafter Mr. Webber was sent to this mission. In 1840, Garrett and Jenkins were appointed as Wesleyan Canarese missionaries, with an authority to build a printing press and a mission-house. Thus was established the Wesleyan Mission Press, with the funding coming from English gentry. The missionaries started to preach in the streets of the petah in the early hours of the day. The sermon was simple Christian concepts such as unity of God, atonement of Christ, etc.<ref name=Arthur>{{cite book|last1=Arthur|first1=William|title=A Mission To The Mysore With Scenes And Facts Illustrative Of India, Its People And Its Religion|date=1850|publisher=Partridge and Oakey|location=London|pages=163–164|url=https://archive.org/details/missiontomysorw00arth|accessdate=24 November 2015}}</ref>
==Thomas Hodson's Account of the Bangalore Petah, 1856== Thomas Hodson in 1856, describes Bangalore as consisting of two parts - the [[Bangalore Cantonment|Cantonment]] where the soldiers lived and [[Tamil language|Tamil]] was primarily spoken, and the Old Town or the native town ([[Bengaluru Pete|Bangalore Pete]]) where [[Canarese|Kannada]] was the main language. In both parts a total of 130,000 Indians lived.<ref name=Offering1857>{{cite journal|last1=Hodson|first1=Thomas|title=Bangalore: Wesleyan Wayside Preaching-Place|journal=Wesleyan Juvenile Offering|date=July 1857|volume=XIV|pages=72–74|url=https://archive.org/details/wesleyanjuvenil12socigoog|accessdate=11 November 2015|publisher=Wesleyan Mission-House|location=London}}</ref> Further he describes the shops of the Bangalore petah, with mud being used for the walls and the floor, wooden pillars and clay used for flat roofs. There were no windows or any protection from the dust, with a mat from the rooftop for shade. At night, the shops were secured by wooden shutters. The shop-keeper sat on the floor of the shop, or on one of the lower shelves. The traders were cloth merchants, grocers, gold smiths, etc. The shops sold sugarcane, coconut, bananas, rice, sweets which were hung on a string and various grains which were kept in baskets with were smeared with cow-dung. Water carriers carrying water was a common site. There were thousands of moneys which created mischief, but were unharmed by the natives due to their religious beliefs.<ref name=Offering1856>{{cite journal|last1=Hodson|first1=Richard G|title=A Bazar, or Shop, in One of the Principal Streets of Bangalore|journal=Wesleyan Juvenile Offering|date=September 1856|volume=XIII|url=https://archive.org/details/wesleyanjuvenil18socigoog|accessdate=10 November 2015|publisher=Wesleyan Mission House|location=London}}</ref>
==Sketches== Thomas Hodson made several sketches about the life in the [[Bengaluru Pete|Bangalore Petah]] and the [[Kingdom of Mysore|Mysore State]]. Many of these were published as engravings in the 'Wesleyan Juvenile Offering'. The original colour sketches are in museums and in private collections. Some of Hodson's sketches are with the [[Museum of Sydney]], The Rocks.
A series of sketches associated with Thomas Hodson, currently in the possession of the [[Museum of Sydney]] could unfortunately not be displayed here, due to licensing issues. It can be seen at these links below: * [http://collection.hht.net.au/images_linked/42467/L2007_212_1.jpg Sketch 1]: School and schoolhouse, Bangalore - Hodson's letter Dec 24 1836 / Thomas Hodson (1836). The present premises of the [[United Mission School]] and Unity Buildings. The Kempe Gowda Tower of Lalbagh can be seen at a distance.<ref name=HHT /> * [http://collection.hht.net.au/images_linked/42468/L2007_212_4.jpg Sketch 2]: First examination of boys by Rev. T. Hodson in Rajah's Palace / artist unknown (1841). Shows the students of the Wesleyan Mission School at Mysore being examined at the Palace of the Maharaja.<ref name=HHT2>{{cite web|title=First examination of boys by Rev. T. Hodson in Rajah's Palace|url=http://collection.hht.net.au/firsthhtpictures/fullRecordPicture.jsp?recnoListAttr=recnoList&recno=42468|website=Historic House Trust, NSW|accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> * [http://collection.hht.net.au/images_linked/42455/L2007_114_3a.jpg Sketch 3]: The Wesleyan Mission Chapel re-built by the Revd. J. Garrett 1846 (Drawn by J Rozario [?] Junior Scholar High School)(1846)<ref name=HHT3>{{cite web|title=The Wesleyan Mission Chapel re-built by the Revd. J. Garrett 1846 (Drawn by J Rozario [?] Junior Scholar High School)|url=http://collection.hht.net.au/firsthhtpictures/fullRecordPicture.jsp?recnoListAttr=recnoList&recno=42455|website=Historic House Trust, NSW|accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> * [http://collection.hht.net.au/images_linked/42454/L2007_114_1.jpg Sketch 4]: Front of temporary Mission House, [[Gubbi|Goobie]], Mysore, India / artist unknown (1837)<ref name=HHT4>{{cite web|title=Front of temporary Mission House, Goobie [Mysore, India]|url=http://collection.hht.net.au/firsthhtpictures/fullRecordPicture.jsp?recnoListAttr=recnoList&recno=42454|website=Historic House Trust, NSW|accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> * [http://collection.hht.net.au/images_linked/42263/L2007_114_2.jpg Sketch 5]: [[Gubbi|Goobie]] Chapel, Mysore, India, opened June 12 1860 / artist unknown (1860)<ref name=HHT5>{{cite web|title=Goobbe Chapel [Mysore, India], opened June 12th 1860 / artist unknown|url=http://collection.hht.net.au/firsthhtpictures/fullRecordPicture.jsp?recnoListAttr=recnoList&recno=42263|website=Historic House Trust, NSW|accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref>

Thomas Hodson)<ref name=Offering1855c>{{cite journal|last1=Hodson|first1=Thomas|title=Missionary Tour by the Rev. Thomas Hodson|journal=Wesleyan Juvenile Offering|date=December 1855|volume=XII|pages=138|url=https://archive.org/details/wesleyanjuvenil16socigoog|accessdate=12 November 2015|publisher=Wesleyan Missionary Society|location=London}}</ref> </gallery>
==Notable works== * ''An Elementary Grammar of the Kannada, or Canarese Language'' (1864)<ref name=Grammar>{{cite book|last1=Hodson|first1=T|title=An Elementary Grammar of Kannada or Canarese Language|date=1864|publisher=Wesleyan Mission Press|location=Bangalore|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=ozwLAwAAQBAJ&pg=PP1&lpg=PP1&dq=An+Elementary+Grammar+of+the+Kannada,+or+Canarese+Language&source=bl&ots=d3ahaDmGJQ&sig=kwViah-f4GPa3yNadm5NWaJ3eFs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj_-b_nkKjJAhXELaYKHcA_ANoQ6AEIJzAD#v=onepage&q=An%20Elementary%20Grammar%20of%20the%20Kannada%2C%20or%20Canarese%20Language&f=false|accessdate=24 November 2015}}</ref> * ''Old Daniel, or, Memoir of a converted Hindoo: with observations on mission work in the Goobbe circuit and description of village life in India'' (1877)<ref name=OldDaniel />
== See also == *[[Hudson Memorial Church, Bangalore]] *[[Rice Memorial Church, Bangalore]] *[[United Mission School]] *[[William Arthur Memorial Church, Gubbi]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Sculpture in Paris]] to [[Category:Sculptures in Paris]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Italic title}}{{No footnotes|date=May 2017}} [[File:Place de Fontenoy, UNESCO székház (Breuer Marcell). Fortepan 87545.jpg|thumb|Travertine sculpture in front of the [[World Heritage Centre]] in Paris in 1971]]
'''''UNESCO Reclining Figure 1957–58''''' is a sculpture by [[Henry Moore]]. It was made in a series of scales, from a small plaster [[maquette]], through a half-size working model made in plaster and cast in bronze (LH 415), to a full-size version carved in Roman [[travertine]] marble in 1957–1958 (LH 416). The final work was installed in 1958 at the [[World Heritage Centre]], the headquarters of [[UNESCO]] (the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation) at the [[Place de Fontenoy]] in Paris. This was Moore's last major public commission in which he created a new work for a specific site; he afterwards generally worked from an existing sketch or model.
==Background== Moore was commissioned in 1955 to create a sculpture for the piazza in front of UNESCO's new headquarters in Paris, designed by the architect [[Marcel Breuer]]. Early ideas included groups of standing or seated figures, such as ''[[Draped Reclining Woman 1957–58]]'' and ''[[Draped Seated Woman 1957–58]]'', but he settled on a single and more abstract reclining figure for the UNESCO commission. Some of his early drawings are held by the [[British Museum]].
==Description== Moore took several maquettes to Paris in February 1957 for UNESCO representatives to select the best one. The selected sculpture depicts the abstracted form of a reclining female human figure, with recognisable arms, torso, and legs, and a disproportionately small head, with hollows representing eyes. Parallels can be drawn with his early stone ''[[Reclining Figure 1929]]'' and his elmwood ''[[Reclining Figure 1935–6]]''. Moore made the suggestion that the final work should be carved in white stone, to contrast with the dark windows of the building behind, rather than casting it in bronze as originally intended.
==Working model== [[File:Moore Große liegende Frauenfigur 1957 Zürich.jpg|thumb|Bronze working model in Zurich in 2010]]
Moore completed a half-size working plaster model in August 1957, which measures {{convert|235|cm}}. This model was made by applying layers of plaster to an armature, the surface of which was then worked with chisels and other tools.
The plaster working model is held by the [[Art Gallery of Ontario]]. The working model (LH 415) was cast in bronze in edition of 7 (5 plus and artists copy, plus one extra cast made for the Tate Gallery), in 1959–1961: three at the [[Corinthian Art Bronze Foundry]] in London, two at {{ill|Fonderie Susse|fr}} in Paris, and two at the [[Hermann Noack]] foundry in Berlin. One example of the {{convert|730|kg}} bronze is held by the Tate Gallery (cast 2/5). Other examples are held in the collections of the [[Carnegie Museum of Art]] in Pittsburgh, the [[Chicago Art Institute]], the [[Stedelijk Museum]] in Amsterdam (cast 4/5), and the [[Kunsthaus Zürich]] (cast 5/5).
==Full-size sculpture== The completed plaster working model was sent to the Société S. Henraux quarry at {{ill|Querceta|it}}, near [[Seravezza]] and close to [[Carrara]] in northern Italy, in September 1957, where it was copied as a full-size version using four large blocks of Roman travertine marble. Moore visited frequently to check on how the work was progressing, and to finish parts roughed out by the Italian workmen. He took his wife Irina and daughter Mary on one trip, and instituted a tradition of taking regular summer holidays in the area, later buying his own cottage.
The final sculpture (LH 416) was finished in mid-1958, over {{convert|16|ft}} long and {{convert|8|ft}} high, and weighing 38 tons, making it one of Moore's largest sculptures. It was installed near the new Y-shaped UNESCO building at the [[Place de Fontenoy]] in Paris in October 1958, and it was in place when the building was inaugurated the following month. The sculpture was moved in 1965, when UNESCO extended its offices, and it is now sited near Building IV.
==References== * [http://www.unesco.org/artcollection/NavigationAction.do?idOeuvre=3066 Moore, Henry (1898–1986), Reclining Figure], UNESCO works of art collection * [http://www.unesco.org/visit/uk/notices/moore.htm "Reclining Figure" (1958)], UNESCO * [http://www.ago.net/henry-moore-sculpture-centre The Henry Moore Sculpture Centre], Art Gallery of Ontario * [http://catalogue.henry-moore.org/objects/22804 UNESCO Reclining Figure, LH 416], Henry Moore Foundation * [http://catalogue.henry-moore.org/objects/15124 Working Model for UNESCO Reclining Figure, LH 415 cast 4], Henry Moore Foundation * [http://catalogue.henry-moore.org/objects/15493 Working Model for UNESCO Reclining Figure, LH 415 cast 0], Henry Moore Foundation * [http://www.artic.edu/aic/collections/artwork/11441?search_no=1&index=6 Maquette for UNESCO Reclining Figure, 1957], Art Institute Chicago * [http://www.tate.org.uk/art/research-publications/henry-moore/henry-moore-om-ch-working-model-for-unesco-reclining-figure-r1171983 Henry Moore, Working Model for UNESCO Reclining Figure 1957, cast c. 1959–61], Tate Gallery * [http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/moore-working-model-for-unesco-reclining-figure-t00390 Working Model for UNESCO Reclining Figure], Tate Gallery * [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=pzqg4l-ce7oC&pg=PA71 Henry Moore – Writings and Conversations], pp. 71–72, 286–87
{{Henry Moore}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:UNESCO Reclining Figure 1957-58}} [[Category:1958 sculptures]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in France]] [[Category:Sculptures in Paris]] [[Category:Sculptures by Henry Moore]] [[Category:Sculptures of women]] [[Category:Stone sculptures in France]] [[Category:UNESCO]]

revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Wilfried Behre|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
'''Wilfried Behre,''' (born 1956 in [[Hanover]], [[Germany]]) is an artist and sculptor. ==Life== Work in several goldsmith workshops, student of the Japanese stone sculptor [[Makoto Fujiwara]] at the [[University of Applied Sciences and Arts in Hanover]] where he was examined as “Master student” (Meisterschüler) in 1992. Internationally active with sculptures in Germany, India, Malaysia and Vietnam. In 1994 Professor at the international Summer academy of fine arts in [[Salzburg]], Austria. 1987 until 1990 co-founder and 1st Chairman of the "''AUE-Creativeschool''"" in [[Hanover]]. more: www.stoneart-behre.de
==Abbreviated list of works and Exhibitions==
* 1989 Begin of the project "''Global Stoneline''" with the creation of seven red [[granite]] sculptures at the river [[Leine]] and the lake [[Maschsee]] in [[Hanover]]. * 1990 Public art action: "''Object of Christmastrees''". * 1991 A [[marble]] sculpture on the summit of the mountain "Salzburger Hochthron" (1896m) in [[Austria]] and several sculptures in joint work for the "''Toskanatrakt''" in [[Salzburg]]. * 1991 Joint work: Memorial stones for the victims of the [[Gulf war]] at the "Opernplatz [[Hanover]]", public handing over to the prime minister of the state of [[Lower Saxony]], [[Gerhard Schröder]]. * 1992 Fountain in the foyer of "''Blind peoples association''" ("Blindenverband") in [[Hanover]], continued work on the project "''Global Stoneline''" and receipt of a grant from the state of [[Lower Saxony]]. * 1994 A sculpture for the kindergarten of [[Fürstenbrunn]] near [[Salzburg]], [[Austria]]. * 1995 Sculpture "''Sun fountain''" ("Solarbrunnen"), [[Hanover]]. * 1996/1997 Solo exhibition at the art society of [[Gehrden]] by [[Hanover]], continued work on the project "''Global Stoneline''" and the "''Wishing stone''" ("Wünschestein"). * 1998 Solo exhibition in the [[Marktkirche, Hanover|Marktkirche]], [[Hanover]]. * 1998/2000 8 [[granite]] sculptures for the new built Computerscience building at [[University of Hanover]]. * 2000/2001 [[Expo 2000]]-project "''Town as garden''" ("Stadt als Garten"), 12 [[limestone]] sculptures on the hill [[Kronsberg]] (118m), view point of the World Exhibition ([[Expo 2000]]) in [[Hanover]], * 2001 [[Goa]] ([[India]]), seven [[granite]] sculptures continuing the concept "''Global Stoneline''", of which four sculptures were created by Wilfried Behre (shaped only on the side facing the ground, partly polished). * 2003 Completion of seven [[granite]] sculptures in [[Malaysia]] at the shore of the [[South China Sea]] as part of the "''Global Stoneline''" project. * 2004 Continuing work on a [[granite]] sculpture (14 tons) near the lake [[Maschsee]] in [[Hanover]]. * 2007 Global Stoneline in Nord Vietnam, Hai Phong, seven green granite sculpture * Fountain Sculpture Norway Granit (ca.14t) * 2009 Professor in [[China Academy of Art]], and fountain sculpture China Granit * more info: www.stoneart-behre.de
==External links== {{Commonscat}} * [http://www.stoneart-behre.de/ Homepage of Wilfried Behre] * [http://www.aue-kreativschule.de/ Homepage of the AUE-Creativeschool in [[Hanover]], [[Germany]]] (in German) * [http://www.summeracademy.at/en/index.php Homepage of the International Summer academy of fine arts] in [[Salzburg]], [[Austria]] * [http://www.kunstverein-gehrden.de/ Art society of Gehrden] by [[Hanover]], [[Germany]] (in German)
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Behre, Wilfried}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:German artists]] [[Category:China Academy of Art]] [[Category:People from Hanover]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Zuriel Oduwole | image = Zuriel Oduwole with hat.jpg | image_size = 220 | caption = Zuriel, during a 2015 interview | birth_name = Zuriel Elise Oduwole | birth_date = c. {{birth year and age|2002}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], United States | nationality = American | occupation = {{flatlist| *[[Child advocate|Education advocate]] *film maker *writer}} | years_active = 2012–present | notable_works = {{plainlist| *''[[The Ghana Revolution]]'' *''[[A Promising Africa]]''}} | organization = Dream Up, Speak Up, Stand Up | website = {{URL|www.zurieloduwole.com}} }}
[[File:Zuriel Oduwole meets Secretary of State John Kerry in DC.jpg|thumb|Zuriel meets Secretary of State John Kerry in Washington DC]] '''Zuriel Elise Oduwole''' is an American teenage education advocate and [[film maker]] best known for her works on the advocacy for the education of girls in Africa. She is of [[Nigeria]]n and [[Mauritian]] descent<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/30/africa/zuriel-oduwole-filmmaker/index.html|title=Zuriel Oduwole - Film Maker|last=|first=|date=30 April 2015|work=CNN|access-date=|via=|accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> Her advocacy has since made her the youngest person to be profiled by ''[[Forbes]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bellanaija.com/2014/02/24/meet-inspiring-11-year-old-zuriel-oduwole-watch-her-ebonylife-interview/|title=Meet Inspiring 11 Year-Old Zuriel Oduwole! Watch her Ebonylife Interview|work=[[BellaNaija]]|date=24 February 2014|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref> In November 2014, at age 12, Zuriel became the world's youngest filmmaker to have a self-produced and self-edited work after her film showed in two movie chains,<ref name="zu">{{cite news|url=http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/2015/11/wonderkid-zuriel-oduwole-takes-on-michael-jackson-in-new-documentary/|title=Wonderkid Zuriel Oduwole takes on Michael Jackson in new documentary|work=[[The Guardian (Nigeria)|The Guardian]]|date=23 November 2014|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref><ref name="zuriel">{{cite news|url=http://www.edition.cnn.com/2015/04/30/africa/zuriel-oduwole-filmmaker/|title=She's made 4 films, interviewed 14 heads of state – oh, and she's only 12|work=[[CNN]]|last=Said-Moorhouse|first=Lauren|date=30 April 2015|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref> and then went on to screen in [[Ghana]], [[England]], [[South Africa]], and [[Japan]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ynaija.com/nigerian-13-year-old-film-maker-zuriel-oduwole-featured-cnbc-africa-watch/|title=13-year-old Nigerian filmmaker, Zuriel Oduwole featured on CNBC Africa (WATCH) - YNaija|last=Peters|first=Oreoluwa|date=2016-05-08|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tanzaniatoday.co.tz/news/cnbc-profiles-13-year-old-film-maker---zuriel-oduwole|title=CNBC Profiles 13 Year Old Film Maker - ZURIEL ODUWOLE {{!}} Magazeti ya leo{{!}} Tanzania News {{!}}Tanzania Today|website=www.tanzaniatoday.co.tz|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://africanwomenincinema.blogspot.com/2016/03/girl-filmmaker-zuriel-oduwole-using-my.html|title=AFRICAN WOMEN IN CINEMA BLOG: Girl filmmaker Zuriel Oduwole: "…using my documentaries to tell Africa's story."|last=Ellerson|first=Beti|date=2016-03-03|website=AFRICAN WOMEN IN CINEMA BLOG|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref>
Oduwole has met with 24 presidents and prime ministers in line with her education advocacy work. Some of these include the leaders of [[Jamaica]], [[Nigeria]], [[Kenya]], [[Tanzania]], [[Malawi]], [[Liberia]], [[South Sudan]], [[Malta]], [[St. Vincent & the Grenadines]], [[Guyana]] and [[Namibia]]. She has also appeared in popular television stations including [[CNBC]], [[Bloomberg TV]], [[BBC]] and [[CNN]].<ref name="zuriel" /> In 2013, Oduwole was listed in the ''[[New African|New African Magazine]]''{{'}}s list of "100 Most Influential People in Africa".<ref name=":2">{{cite news|url=http://thenationonlineng.net/zuriel-oduwole-makes-africas-influential-people-list/|title=Zuriel Oduwole makes Africa's most Influential people list|date=2 December 2013|work=[[The Nation (Nigeria)|The Nation]]|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref> [[File:With Ashesi University students - Ghana.jpg|thumb|Zuriel after Addressing Ashesi University Students - Ghana.]]
==Early life and career== [[File:Zuriel Oduwole Speaks with Nigerias President Buhari.jpg|thumb|229x229px|Zuriel Oduwole with President Buhari]] Zuriel Oduwole was born in [[Los Angeles]], U.S to a Nigerian father and a Mauritian mother. Her first venture into media and advocacy was in 2012 when she entered a school competition with a documentary film about Africa titled ''[[The Ghana Revolution]]''.<ref name=rev>{{cite news|url=http://bioreports.net/news/my-encounters-with-african-presidents-others-says-10-year-old-zuriel-oduwole/|title=MY ENCOUNTERS WITH AFRICAN PRESIDENTS, OTHERS SAYS 10 YEAR OLD, ZURIEL ODUWOLE|work=Bio Reports|last=Otufodunrin|first=Lekan|date=13 August 2013|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref> For this she conducted her first presidential interviews, when she met with two former presidents of Ghana: [[Jerry Rawlings]] and [[John Kufuor]].
In 2013, after the release of her documentary film titled ''The 1963 OAU Formation'', Zuriel Oduwole was profiled in ''[[Forbes Magazine]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnbcafrica.com/video/?bctid=4121295470001|title=MEET THE YOUNGEST FILM MAKER IN THE WORLD – ZURIEL ODUWOLE|work=[[CNBC]]|date=19 March 2014|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref> As part of this second documentary, she interviewed the President of Malawi ( [[Joyce Banda]] ), the President of Tanzania ( [[Jakaya Kikwete]] ) and the President of Mauritius ( [[Kailash Purryag|Rakeshwar Purryag]] ). In March 2013, Oduwole formally started a project called "Dream Up, Speak Up, Stand Up", a campaign which was first launched at the [[Lagos Business School]]'s [[Pan-Atlantic University]], for the advocacy and promotion of girl-child education in Africa.<sup>[[Zuriel Oduwole#cite note-28|[28]]]</sup> [[File:With Guyana President @ The UN.jpg|thumb|Zuriel Speaks to Guyana President at the United Nations]] In 2014 at age 12, her self-produced documentary film titled ''[[A Promising Africa]]'' was screened in five countries.<ref name="zu" /> On 21 April 2014, Oduwole was listed as the most Powerful 11 year old in the world by New York ''[[Business Insider]]'''s in their listing of "World's Most Powerful Person at Every Age".<ref name=":0">{{cite news | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/most-powerful-people-in-the-world-2014-4?op=1 | title=The Most Powerful Person at Every Age | work=[[Business Insider]] | date=21 April 2014 | accessdate=15 December 2015 |author1=Melissa, Stanger |author2=Melia, Robinson }}</ref> In February 2015, ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle Magazine]]'' listed her in their annual feature of "33 Women Who Changed The World", alongside Fed Reserve Chairwoman [[Janet Yellen]] and President of General Motors, [[Mary Barra]].<ref name=":1">{{cite news | url=http://thenet.ng/2015/02/young-nigerian-filmmaker-zuriel-oduwole-honoured-alongside-angelina-jolie-others/ | title=Young Nigerian filmmaker, Zuriel Oduwole honoured alongside Angelina Jolie, others | work=[[Nigeria Entertainment Today]] | date=23 February 2015 | accessdate=15 December 2015 | author=Hassan, Sanusi}}</ref>
The [[University of Pretoria]] in South Africa [aka TUKS] invited her to speak to their student body in March 2015 as a film maker, to give the students an insight into how to communicate and tell the story of global events, from a specific perspective – as part of their Humanities series.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.perdeby.co.za/sections/entertainment/events/4223-zuriel-oduwole-visits-tuks|title=Zuriel Oduwole visits Tuks|last=Editor|first=Web|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref>
[[File:Zuriel On Set Directing 4-23-15.jpg|thumb|Zuriel directing on set - Los Angeles]] In April 2015, the [[Ivy League]]'s [[Columbia University]] in [[New York City|New York]], U.S invited her as a featured speaker at their African Economic Forum conference, as well as a segment panelist, to speak about the potentials of the new Africa.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.africanbusinesscentral.com/2015/04/04/columbia-university-announces-line-up-of-speakers-ahead-of-april-11-african-economic-forum-aef-in-new-york-city/|title=Columbia University announces line-up of speakers ahead of April 11 African Economic Forum (AEF) in New York City|website=African Business Central|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://homecomingrevolution.com/7-reasons-to-attend-columbia-universitys-africa-economic-forum-in-new-york/|title=7 reasons to attend Columbia University’s Africa Economic Forum in New York - Homecoming Revolution|date=2015-04-08|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref>
[[Alpha Condé|President Alpha Conde of Guinea]] met and spoke with Zuriel in May 2015, as part of an information documentary she was doing on the [[Ebola virus disease|Ebola]] Virus, which started in his country [[Guinea]] [before ravaging Sierra Leone and Liberia] to understand the impact on the economies of the region, as well as the effect on children's education. President Conde was her 15th world leader she would meet to talk about pertinent and pressing issues.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thenigerianvoice.com/news/181722/1/zuriel-oduwole-interviews-her-15th-world-leader-he-the-president-of-guinea-for-documentary-short.html|title=Zuriel Oduwole Interviews Her 15th World Leader, H.E The President of Guinea/ For Documentary Short|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref>
As part of their global #LikeAGirl campaign to shore up girls confidence as they entered adolescence, global giant [[Procter & Gamble]] engaged Zuriel in June 2015 to create a short documentary about the education of girls about puberty, and the support needed during this period of their lives. She wrote, narrated and produced the video for the campaign with the theme ''Unstoppable Like A Girl''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/prnewser/always-highlights-unstoppable-csr-work-in-like-a-girl-follow-up/116173|title=Always Highlights #Unstoppable CSR Work in ‘Like a Girl’ Follow-Up|website=www.adweek.com|access-date=2016-10-30}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Always|title=Being Unstoppable #LikeAGirl - A Film by Zuriel Oduwole|date=2015-07-07|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KBxG08yr4uI|accessdate=2016-10-30}}</ref>
While attending global events during the 70th [[United Nations General Assembly]] session in New York in September 2015, she met [[David A. Granger]], the [[President of Guyana]] on the sidelines of the General Assembly, to speak about the disputed [[Guayana Esequiba|Esequiba Oil territory]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201510052748.html|title=Nigeria: Peace Ambassador, Zuriel Oduwole, Meets 16th World Leader At UN|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref>
In December 2015, she formally launched her DUSUSU Foundation aimed at building partnerships with corporation and individuals, to develop the education capabilities of children, but especially the girl child, across the globe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://guardian.ng/news/zuriel-oduwole-launches-her-foundation-in-lagos/|title=Zuriel Oduwole launches her foundation in Lagos|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref> As a film maker, she launched her film making 101 Initiative for youths in [[Windhoek]], [[Namibia]] in March 2016 and [[Lagos]], [[Nigeria]] in June 2016, teaching some of Africa's poorest children basic film making skills, so they have practical skills they can use in gainful or self-employment, as young adults.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tanzaniatoday.co.tz/news/zuriel-teaches-youths-film-makingspeaks--tedx-in-lagos|title=Zuriel Teaches Youths Film Making/Speaks @ TEDx in Lagos {{!}} Magazeti ya leo{{!}} Tanzania News {{!}}Tanzania Today|website=www.tanzaniatoday.co.tz|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newera.com.na/2016/03/02/worlds-youngest-filmmaker-zuriel-oduwole-inpires-namibian-youth/|title=World’s youngest filmmaker, Zuriel Oduwole inpires Namibian youth|last=Corporation|first=New Era Publication|date=2016-03-02|website=New Era Newspaper Namibia|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref>
In April 2016 at age 13, she was invited as the keynote speaker at the annual [[Maryland State Department of Education]]'s Early Childhood Educational conference at [[Ocean City, Maryland]], addressing more than 600 adult delegates on how she sees the education of future US leaders developing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mscca.org/conference-by-the-sea/|title=Conference by The Sea - Maryland State Childcare Association|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref> Later in June 2016, she was invited as the featured speaker as well as a panelist at the annual Women in Entertainment Luncheon, in Los Angeles, California, U.S.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stubhubcenter.com/charitable-foundation/donation-guide/women-entertainment-luncheon-2016|title=Women in Entertainment Luncheon 2016 {{!}} StubHub Center|last=Center|first=StubHub|website=www.stubhubcenter.com|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref> [[File:Arrives at SAFTA Awards Johannesurg - SA.jpg|thumb|Zuriel Oduwole Arrives at 2015 SAFTA Film Awards Johannesburg - SA]] The Guardian Newspaper in late June 2016 signed her on as a Columnist to share her insight on issues as seen by a younger generation and giving her a section and segment for periodic writing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://guardian.ng/features/when-would-the-lion-learn-to-write/|title=When would the lion learn to write?|access-date=2016-10-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://guardian.ng/contributors/zuriel-oduwole/|title=Zuriel Oduwole|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref> She became a [[TED (conference)|TEDx]] circuit speaker when she headlined the TEDx Gbagada event in July 2016 as the featured speaker, talking about the inter-connectivity between the past and future generations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2016/08/27/tedxkids-spark-conversation-innovation-in-lagos/|title=TEDxKids Spark Conversation, Innovation in Lagos|last=Editor|first=Online|date=2016-08-26|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=TEDx Talks|title=Can Kids Make a Global Impact {{!}} Zuriel Oduwole {{!}} TEDxKids@Gbagada|date=2016-10-27|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XuTAWVpMGAc|accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref>
At the 71st United Nations [UN] General Assembly events in New York in September 2016, Zuriel was invited to speak on how the effects of climate change is significantly affecting the education of children in the Pacific Island region. She met to discuss these issues afterwards with the [[Prime Minister of Samoa]] - H.E. Tuilaepa Malielegaoi and the Prime Minister of Tuvalu, H.E. [[Enele Sopoaga]]. She was invited to meet the new Jamaica Prime Minister - H.E. [[Andrew Holness]], to understand how [[Global warming|Global Warming]] is affecting countries in the Caribbean region also <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tanzaniatoday.co.tz/news/zuriel-speaks-at-the-un---supports-climate-change-initiative|title=Zuriel Speaks At The UN - Supports Climate Change Initiative {{!}} Magazeti ya leo{{!}} Tanzania News {{!}}Tanzania Today|website=www.tanzaniatoday.co.tz|access-date=2016-10-02}}</ref>
TRT World news interviewed and featured her on their Newsmakers section after her participation at the UN events <ref>{{Citation|last=TRT World|title=The Newsmakers: Sugar coating the truth? And an interview with Zuriel Oduwole|date=2016-09-30|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zpvr5fNod_4|accessdate=2016-10-02}}</ref>
In October 2016, she met with her 23rd World Leader, the [[President of Malta]] Her Excellency Mary Louise Preca, to share her ideas on building a network of female world leaders to tackle the issue of "out of school children", especially girls, around the world.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://guardian.ng/business-services/zuriel-oduwole-builds-a-powerful-coalition-of-female-world-leaders/|title=Zuriel Oduwole builds a powerful coalition of female world leaders|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref>
As part of activities to commemorate their 11th annual Kreole festival from November 22–25, the government of Mauritius invited Zuriel Oduwole to be the special guest for the years events. Apart from being a judge for the film competition during the festival chaired by the Deputy Prime Minister [[Xavier Luc Duval]], she taught 150 underprivileged children basic film making skills from the [[Port Louis]] municipality as a film maker herself, and was a guest at the African night concert at the country's Citadel center in Port Louis along with Zambian First Lady, H.E. [[Esther Lungu]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lemauricien.com/article/quatre-bornes-zuriel-oduwole-presidente-du-jury-la-finale-des-courts-metrages|title=À QUATRE-BORNES : Zuriel Oduwole, présidente du Jury de la finale des courts-métrages {{!}} Le Mauricien|website=www.lemauricien.com|access-date=2016-11-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lexpress.mu/article/294459/zuriel-oduwole-latout-lafrique-cest-sa-population|title=Zuriel Oduwole: "L’atout de l’Afrique, c’est sa population "|date=2016-11-25|newspaper=lexpress.mu|language=fr|access-date=2016-11-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mbc.intnet.mu/article/zuriel-oduwole-la-plus-jeune-r%C3%A9alisatrice-cin%C3%A9matographique-au-monde-est-%C3%A0-mauricevideo|title=Zuriel Oduwole, la plus jeune réalisatrice cinématographique au monde, est à Maurice.[VIDEO]|website=mbc.intnet.mu|access-date=2016-11-26}}</ref>
In January 11, 2017 the Rt Hon [[John Kerry]] met Zuriel in Washington DC to commend her for what he called her 'clarity of purpose' in recognizing a major global developmental issue - Girls Education, and taking on the challenge head on. He also lauded her film making class for unemployed youths, which he said was making a tangible difference.
In February 2015, President [[Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović|Kolinda Grabar-Kitarovic]] of Croatia met with Zuriel Oduwole to commend her work on Girls Education and to learn how her basic 'Film Making 101' skill transfer programs could make a difference for the youth in Croatia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://govandbusinessjournal.com.ng/president-kolinda-kitarovic-of-croatia-meets-zuriel-oduwole/|title=President Kolinda Kitarovic of Croatia meets Zuriel Oduwole {{!}} The Government and Business Journal|last=administrator|website=govandbusinessjournal.com.ng|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2017/02/13/croatian-president-hosts-rising-nigerian-education-for-girls-advocate-zuriel-oduwole/|title=Croatian President Hosts Rising Nigerian Education-for-Girls Advocate, Zuriel Oduwole|last=Editor|first=Online|date=2017-02-13|newspaper=THISDAYLIVE|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=TV360NIGERIA|title=Zuriel meets president of Croatia to discuss Education, Gender issues|date=2017-02-15|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=99&v=jp8tf9gfOYQ|accessdate=2017-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://trumpetmediagroup.com/the-trumpet/news/zuriel-meets-croatia-president-grabar-kitarovic/|title=Zuriel meets Croatia's President Grabar-Kitarovic|date=2017-02-14|work=Trumpet Media Group|access-date=2017-03-05|language=en-gb}}</ref>
Forbes Afrique featured Zuriel for their February 2017 [Fevrier 2017] issue. The magazine introduced her DUSUSU Foundation and its evolving partnerships with development groups on the continent, such as the [[Dangote Foundation]], for her Gender Development and Skill transfer project initiatives <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.forbesafrique.com/Zuriel-Oduwole-l-ado-qui-bouscule-le-monde-des-adultes_a6369.html|title=Zuriel Oduwole, l’ado qui bouscule le monde des adultes|last=Donna|first=Naomi|newspaper=Forbes Afrique magazine|access-date=2017-02-14|language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://guardian.ng/news/forbes-afrique-features-nigerias-zuriel-oduwole-in-february-edition/|title=Forbes Afrique features Nigeria’s Zuriel Oduwole in February edition|access-date=2017-02-20|language=en-US}}</ref>
Zuriel visited Mexico as an Education Ambassador, speaking to 350 youths in Mexico State and Hidalgo State and taking them through her basic Film Making 101 Class, already conducted in 4 other countries. The City of Pachuca - in Hidalgo state then honored her with an Award and Citation for her global work in the area of Education Development and Girls Equality advocacy<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://govandbusinessjournal.com.ng/city-of-pachuca-welcomes-zuriel-oduwole-to-mexico-as-education-ambassador/|title=City of Pachuca welcomes Zuriel Oduwole to Mexico as Education Ambassador {{!}} The Government and Business Journal|last=administrator|website=govandbusinessjournal.com.ng|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-29}}</ref>
==Awards and recognitions== In October 2013, Oduwole was bestowed with an honorary ambassador title in [[Tanzania]] by Salma Kikwete, and a computer lab in one of the country's schools was named after her.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thenationonlineng.net/zuriel-oduwole-africas-powerful-influential-11-year-old/|title=Zuriel Oduwole: Africa’s most influential 11-year-old|work=[[The Nation (Nigeria)|The Nation]]|date=|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref> Also that year she was listed in the ''[[New African|New African Magazine]]''{{'}}s list of "100 Most Influential People in Africa".<ref name=":2" /> On 21 April 2014, Oduwole was listed as the most Powerful 11 year old in the world by New York ''[[Business Insider]]'''s in their listing of "World's Most Powerful Person at Every Age".<ref name=":0" /> In February 2015, ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle Magazine]]'' listed her in their annual feature of "33 Women Who Changed The World", alongside Fed Reserve Chairwoman [[Janet Yellen]] and President of General Motors, [[Mary Barra]].<ref name=":1" />
On 12 March 2016, Zuriel won the "Woman on The Rise" category at the 2016 edition of the "''New African'' Women Awards".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://pulse.ng/events/new-africa-woman-awards-2016-oby-ezekwesili-zuriel-oduwole-jumoke-adenowo-and-others-emerge-winners-id4794056.html|title=Oby Ezekwesili, Zuriel Oduwole, Jumoke Adenowo and others emerge winners|work=Pulse Nigeria|last=Inyese|first=Amaka|date=12 March 2016|accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://m.mgafrica.com/article/2016-03-15-new-african-women|title=Meet New African Woman magazine's pick of the top 11 women who are changing the game on the continent|work=Mail & Guardian Africa|date=15 March 2016|accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref> In August 2016 at age 14, ''Forbes Afrique'' which is distributed across all 23 Francophone African countries as well as [[France]], [[Belgium]] and [[Switzerland]], featured her in their annual Africa's 100 Most Influential Women's list, alongside the President of Liberia, [[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]] and [[Ameenah Gurib]], President of Mauritius.<sup>[[Zuriel Oduwole#cite note-27|[27]]]</sup>
